Blair's speech, part one: 'It's no wonder the government has taken a knock'

Today I make a further commitment.

Line one of the contract in the next manifesto will be a promise to increase the share of our national wealth spent on education in the next Parliament.

Education. Education. Education. Then. Now. And in the future.

Again, on health, let me set out the scale of our plans, for now and for a second term.

The waiting list pledge has been met.

There are 10,000 more nurses in the NHS.

Every A&E that needs it is being modernised.

The biggest ever hospital building programme is under way.

But we all know. 18 years of neglect isn't put right in three years.

Earlier this year we got the money to plan for a five year record rise in NHS spending. But we are New Labour. We don't just spend.

Alan Milburn and I sat down with people in the NHS and said it's a deal: we provide the cash, you rise to the challenge of modernising the NHS. They responded magnificently.

Our NHS plan is something the party can be proud of. The NHS was the greatest achievement of the post-war Labour government. It was based on a single, clear, enduring value: that healthcare should be based on need not ability to pay. Some objected to that principle then. Some urge us to abandon it now. But this party, the Labour party will never abandon what was one of the greatest civilising acts of emancipation this country has ever known.

Under the plan, for the first time a system of inspection and accountability for all parts of the NHS, with new money to reward good performance.

For the first time, nurses and other health professionals given the bigger roles that their qualifications and expertise deserve.

For the first time local health services and local social services brought closer together in one organisation.

For the first time, the NHS and the private sector in a proper partnership to deliver healthcare.

For the first time, money set aside specifically to get rid of the dirty corridors, the poor food, the mixed sex wards which demoralise patients and staff.

For the first time, new consultants trained within the NHS, paid for by the taxpayer, will give the early years of their service exclusively to National Health Service patients.

Today, as we set out the next steps, I want to focus on cancer.

There will be nobody in this hall, or watching from their homes, who has not seen a friend or family member struck down by cancer.

As things stand, one in every four people in this country will die of cancer.

Under the plan we publish tomorrow, there will be 1000 more cancer specialists over the next six years - up nearly a third.

295 new scanners and radio-therapy machines so that for the first time the NHS can meet proper equipment standards for diagnosing and treating cancer.

By 2003 for the first time the government will be matching pound for pound charity funding for cancer research.

Cancer patients in all parts of the country will get the right drugs at the right time, regardless of where they live. The postcode lottery ended. Waiting times will be cut. Maximum two weeks from GP appointment to first hospital appointment for suspected urgent cases. And, as we increase the number of specialists, a maximum wait of one month from diagnosis to treatment starting.

And because breast cancer kills 11,000 women every year, because it causes so much pain and suffering among Britain's families, we will extend breast cancer screening to all women aged over 65, helping an extra 400,000 women by 2004.

Then on transport, in July John Prescott and Gus Macdonald set out in detail Britain's first ever transport plan, a unique 10 year £180 billion partnership between public and private sector to renew our transport system.

A massive programme for the second term. It will take time. Investment. And a Labour government to see it through.

The Conservatives have made their choice.

They are committed to £16bn of cuts in our investment.

When they made this commitment, I asked for research on what sort of things you'd have to cut over a 12 month period to deliver on a £16bn cuts guarantee. Back came the answer.

20,000 doctors. Cut.

Plus 20,000 prison officers. Cut.

Plus 40,000 nurses. Cut.

Plus 40,000 teachers. Cut.

Plus 40,000 police officers. Cut under the Tory cuts guarantee.

And then: 20 hospitals. Shut.

150 secondary schools. Shut. 500 primary schools. Shut under the Tory cuts guarantee.

And we've still got five billion pounds to go. How will they get there?

The biggest ever rise in child benefit. Cut.

Free TV licences for 3 million pensioners. Cut.

The £150 winter fuel allowance. Cut under the Tory cuts guarantee.

1200 intensive care beds. Cut.

Free eye tests for pensioners. Cut. 250 cancer scanners. Cut.

Half a million nursery places. Cut. 100,000 childcare places. Cut under the Tory cuts guarantee.

And just to round it up to £16 billion, the country's entire arts and sports budget. Cut under the Tory cuts guarantee.

And in every constituency, in every part of this country, we will force every Tory candidate to say where the cuts will fall.

The fourth big choice: a government with the strength to build strong communities, or a government that believes there is no such thing in society.

Crime, anti-social behaviour, racial intolerance, drug abuse, destroy families and communities. They destroy the very respect for others on which society is founded. They blight the life chances of thousands of young people and the quality of life of millions more.

Fail to confront this evil and we will never build a Britain where everyone can succeed.

So we invest to give opportunity. Not just in jobs and services.

Today we set out plans to invest £750million of lottery money in schools and community sport as part of a £1billion investment over three years.

It's a policy we have put together with Trevor Brooking, chairman of Sport England, who has flown here from Sydney and who believes passionately, as I do, that this is not just a sports policy. It's a health policy, an education policy, an anti-crime policy, an anti-drugs policy.

By acknowledging the duty to care, we earn the right to be tough on crime. 4 out of 10 violent crimes are alcohol related. Half of property crime drug-related.

It is time for zero tolerance of the yob culture.

Time to stand up for the pensioner afraid to go out. Time to stand up for the single mothers scared to walk to the shops. Time to stand up to the thugs and the bullies.

Time to tighten bail to deal with the absurdity of people released in the morning committing offences in the afternoon. Time to give the police powers to close pubs where there is fighting.

Time to give them powers to ban drink in public places.

Time to give them the power to impose curfews on children up to 16 and time to use them.

Time to give them the power without the hassle of endless forms and court bureaucracy, to issue fixed penalty fines for loutish behaviour.

Time to give offenders on drugs a choice: get treatment or lose your liberty because society needs protection from you.

These measures require legislation. So will the new and sweeping powers we intend to give to the police and customs to investigate organised crime and to confiscate their assets.

If they need further powers, they will get them.

You don't beat today's drug gangs by applying the Queensberry rules. It is time the law enforcement agencies were able to do as much damage to organised crime as organised crime does to our communities.

We have increased funding for victim support, and given special help to victims of rape and sexual offences, but we need to do more.

- They should get full information about the progress of the case.

- About the sentence, and about the release of the criminal.

- Proper compensation, backed by a Victims' Ombudsman.

And, I believe that the victim of a crime should be able to give a written assessment of the impact of the crime upon them, which should be presented in open court, and taken into account when sentencing decisions are made.

Standing up to criminals. Standing up for victims. Another big project for the second term of a Labour government.

The fifth choice: a government that leads in the world, or a government that retreats into isolation.

This is a world moving closer together. In money and trade; the environment; defence and security; the war against drugs and crime; even today the call for lower oil prices: strength comes through partnership; influence through international engagement.

Standing up for Britain means standing up for our armed services.

Standing up for Britain means know we are stronger with the US if we are stronger in Europe, and stronger in Europe if we are stronger with the US.

Standing up for Britain means standing up for British jobs and British industry.

On the Euro, standing up for Britain means taking the decision in the interests of Britain, not the interests of the internal warfare inside the Tory party.

I believe we should join if the economics are right. At present, they aren't.

But the choice at the election is not whether we join: that decision is for the people in a referendum.

The issue is: do we rule out joining?

Do we rule out even the option?

How is that standing up for Britain, Britain's jobs, Britain's industry, the living standards of Britain's people?

And standing up for Britain means standing up for our values overseas, in Sierra Leone, in Kosovo.

And I say to Milosevic. You lost. Go. Your country and the world has suffered enough.

These are the choices we make.

These are our second term plans.

A ten year plan for a modern NHS. The transformation of secondary education.

A cradle to grave poverty strategy.

A plan to harness new technology to spread prosperity to all. A plan to make our streets safe and our society strong. A 10 year plan for modern transport.

The next steps to full employment.

This is a programme worth fighting for. A second term more radical than the first. A quickening of the pace of reform. The next steps on our journey. All based on our enduring mission, to offer everyone, not just the privileged few, the chance to succeed.

And lighting our path is this belief: that today a strong economy and a strong society are two sides of the same coin.

To succeed as an economy we develop the talents of all.

To be a fair society, we give opportunity to all.

The political consequences are historic; self-interest and the common good are at long last in alliance.

Look at the irony of the Tory years.

The Tories who said only they could manage the economy ended up with boom and bust.

The Tory party that said it would get tough on benefit claimants, ended up spending more on social security than schools and hospitals put together.

The Tory party that said it would stand up for the family, presided over more instability, more single parents on benefit, more truancy, more juvenile crime than any in history.

Why? Because they offered short-term tax cuts that could not be sustained rather than investing for the long-term.

Because they thought there was no such thing as society.

In the world of the 80s that might have been cruel; in the 21st century it simply won't work.

Do you know how much we save from almost 1 million fewer welfare claimants since we took power. £4 billion per annum. Enough for 75,000 nurses and 70,000 teachers.

Do you know how much it would cost to take out private medical insurance, as the Tories want? Over £1500 a year for the average family.

Do you know the cost to the British economy of transport congestion a year? The equivalent of 8p on your income tax.

Do you know why we say this is a learn more, earn more world? Because a graduate earns 40 % more than the average.

On your side for the Tories means nodding along with your prejudices - English language lessons for foreign doctors - you know they're not talking about the Swiss.

But really being on your side is to be there with you on the big questions, on the fundamentals.

What began as a moral crusade is now also the path to prosperity. What started as a belief in the equal worth of all is also a programme for wealth creation.

Realism and idealism at last in harmony.

So when the Tories say: we'll cut Labour's investment and give you tax cuts, it's a fool's game. We will cut tax for people as we can, but will do it in a way that lasts not at the expense of the very stability and investment on which the wealth and security of millions of families depend.

So that is my explanation. That's why I won't take the easy way. Because that way we cannot reach our journey's end.

And all that really stands between us and our destination is confidence. And trust.

The confidence that gives us strength to make the choices; the trust that there is a vision, an end to believe in.

Don't tell me that a country with our history and heritage, that today boasts six of the top ten businesses in the whole of Europe, with London the top business city in Europe, that is a world leader in technology and communication and the businesses of the future, that under us has overtaken France and Italy to become the fourth largest economy in the world, that has the language of the new economy, more brilliant artists, actors and directors than any comparable country in the world, some of the best scientists and inventors in the world, the best armed forces in the world, the best teachers and doctors and nurses, the best people any nation could wish for.

Don't tell me with all that going for us that we do not have the spirit to meet all the challenges before us.

For that is another choice; confidence or cynicism. All we need is the confidence to make the right choice for the future.

Just as we did in the party so, on a larger scale, the same is true for Britain. We are on a journey of renewal. Before us lies a path strewn with the challenges of change.

But the purpose of our journey is not to lose our values as a nation: but to make them live on.

Go to any good secondhand book shop and it won't take you long to spot the book plates of major libraries. My trawl last week included books from the BBC library, Whitelands College (now part of Roehampton) and a major public library.

But it's not just these institutions which are at fault. I refuse to buy anything with the stamp of my own university library because it is just too painful to buy back material over which I thought I had some sort of collective ownership. And this is just the material that gets to the bookshops. If no one wants deleted stock, then university libraries can quietly send it to be pulped.

Shocked at the thought of the book equivalent of the knackers van? The problem of stock deletion is not a new one. Twenty years ago, starting to teach Soviet history, I began to scour second-hand catalogues for older works on Russia. As the small collection grew, a sympathetic librarian warned me to watch out. Sooner or later, he said, someone will ask why we have all this old stuff and it will be up for deletion.

Why does this happen? The key phrase is "stock management". If there was ever a time when librarians saw themselves as preserving a body of published knowledge, then this is long gone. Now they are thought of as gardeners who know the value of ruthless pruning.

This pruning is best done quietly. The librarian who has just written my own university library's first public stock management document was told by other librarians that she was just making trouble for herself. But at least it will lead to an open debate.

What will change is another matter. There is a fundamental conflict between the library's role in preserving knowledge, and the constraints under which it can achieve that.

Some stock management is necessary. The 10 copies of a textbook soon become redundant when a new edition comes out - or nine of them do. But the pressure to delete stock goes way beyond this. At its root is money and good old British short-termism. Only the best-funded academic libraries can afford to plan the repository and other space to maintain collections. Even they struggle.

For everyone else, the starting point is that space costs money. This is why most public libraries sold off or pulped huge and valuable subterranean collections long ago. Now, what you see is more or less what you get.

Libraries are now "learning centres", and must fit in computers and study rooms to create attractive study areas rather than maintain basements full of dusty shelving.

Then there is the cost of preservation. Paper crumbles quite quickly, and the choice is often one between allowing magazines and newspapers to disintegrate on the shelves or pulping them.This is why so few are interested in the papers that the British Library no longer wants.

Student needs are defined in terms of whether there are enough copies of the most recent edition of the textbooks on their reading list.

And there is the tension between the needs of undergraduate and postgraduate students. The latter are few, yet their needs are for stock in depth, which means low usage. In many newer universities the library's research role counts for little.

Then there are the different subject interests. Historians are desperate to preserve older material. Once gone, these items are often lost forever. And that's the problem.

Is there a solution? The obvious one is to develop clearer and longer-term stock management policies. Plus some regional complementarity of collections with guarantees on stock maintenance and a redistribution of funding to facilitate it. In the meantime, the battle to preserve stocks is likely to continue in more underhand ways, so here are some strategies. Firstly, remember that without the support of librarians you are unlikely to succeed. Second, stock turnover is what counts. The first sign of danger is often the "dust check". If it is dusty it must be little used, so blow the dust off key areas. Third, if you take a book or journal off the shelf, never ever put it back as this increases the impression that "the stock has not moved". Fourth, set students lots of exercises which require them to handle the stock.

And if all else fails, put a little money aside for the day when your prized area is deleted. You may only have to outbid the pulping van.

Elizabethan clergy anxiously reporting to the bishop on the state of their parishioners' souls can hardly have imagined they were creating a goldmine for future scholars in a digital age. "Ecclesiastical records may seem rather dry, but they contain an enormous amount about crime and marriage and gender relations," comments Allen Warren, head of York University's history department.

Fears of witchcraft and political upheaval, traces of poverty and disease, the views of ordinary people who did not write but who reveal all sorts of views and assumptions of the time in their wills - the sort of archive built up over centuries by the archdiocese of York is now a magnet for university researchers.

But it is not in a university library. Housed in a picturesque building in the medieval city centre, the Borthwick Institute archive is outgrowing its home and York University is keen to take it under its wing, rehouse it and make it more accessible to scholars as part of an ambitious £7.5m development.

Far from superseding traditional archives, new digital technology has the potential to bring more of them to light and make them more accessible.

The York project is taking place against the background of a revolution in British research libraries. It's a quiet revolution - but the vision that archives and books scattered in different libraries should be seen as a parts of a whole has been gaining ground over the past five years. For researchers it does not matter if the document or book they want to consult is in York, London or Edinburgh, just as long as they can locate it. So a lot of effort is going into cataloguing collections - and inventing bizarre names for them - to create what librarians call a Distributed National Resource.

Logically, this would produce a single integrated "library" covering the country - but that was "overambitious", according to Ronald Milne, director of the Research Support Libraries Programme, which is spending £30m over three years to link university libraries with each other and with public libraries and collections. However, building a distributed national resource in particular disciplines like archaeology or Chinese is, he believes, achievable.

In one sense York is a good example of the new spirit of collaboration. The project is linking the university not only with the Borthwick collection but the National Railway Museum archive in the city and privately held collections in the region. But the York scheme also reveals a tension between national plans and local ambition. The planned £3m humanities research library for the university campus will, it is hoped, put York more firmly on the research map. York is young in university library terms and does not have the breadth of the older collections, as librarian Elizabeth Heaps admits. A library covering history, English, history of art, music, archaeology, languages and philosophy would lure researchers, building on existing cross-disciplinary activity in medieval, women's and 18th-century studies.

"There is a well-developed interdisciplinary culture here," said John Barrell, head of English at York. "But it takes a lot of library resources to do it successfully. We have no problem getting high-quality staff, but in persuading postgraduate students that it is sensible to research here given the quality of library resources in London or America."

The humanities research library will be a hybrid - archives, books and printed material, with microfilm, CD-roms and network computers. "This is our laboratory for the humanities and related disciplines, but it is not all centred on the building and the books we put in it," said Heap.

York is already talking to owners of private collections - in stately homes, for instance. But a recent furore over Keele University's sale of Isaac Newton books donated by a benefactor has made owners nervous about giving collections to universities. Heaps is adamant that York would not sell off books.

Universities are of course eager to promote their own collections, but Milne has found that the promise from his programme set up after the 1996 Anderson Report of funding is inducing them to collaborate , even if with gritted teeth to start with. As no one library can buy all the books and journals or maintain the archives all its users need, closer cooperation and partnership has become a necessity, strongly promoted by Milne: "Some consortia are willing partnerships, some are shotgun marriages where people went in kicking and screaming. Money is a great attraction."

More difficult has been the lack of joined up interdepartmental thought and funding. Universities get money from the higher education funding councils, public libraries from several different departments. It makes collaboration complicated and bureaucratic, though it is happening. The British Library and the School of Oriental and African Studies, for instance, have agreed which Chinese resources each should collect.

Perhaps it is a sign that librarians are taking cooperation to heart that these partnerships have sprouted acronyms by the dozen, from Scone (Scottish Collections Network Extension) project to Casbah, a scheme to identify and map national research resources for Caribbean studies and the history of Black and Asian people in Britain. The Queen's University of Belfast has scooped a couple of particularly neat acronyms. Its Planning Architecture Design Database Ireland has been dubbed Paddi; its Research and Special Collections Available Locally is simply called Rascal.

The internet has done many things to elevate women's lives to the realms of fantasy; electronic flirting allows us to tell huge fibs without the slightest risk of heartbreak ("Yes, people often mistake me for Xena Warrior Princess, honest") and when love goes wrong we can seek round-the-clock comfort from BreakUp Girl, the postfeminist boyfriend advice site. Now, though, women's wildest fantasies are being catered for in an entirely different way, with the booming online literary phenomenon, slash fiction.

The term refers to the use of a stroke or "slash" to signify a homoerotic relationship between two characters from a cult TV show or film. It could be any two personalities such as the hugely popular Star Trek pairing Kirk/Spock or Mulder/Krycek from The X-Files. The only restriction is that the characters should not have a sexual relationship in the "real" series.

On the face of it, this looks like just another geeky outpouring from the net's lunatic fringe. Certainly there is no obvious connection between this level of fan writing and women's erotic empowerment. Yet surf through a few typical sites and something unexpected emerges: almost all the stories are written by heterosexual women. Some offer truly bizarre pairings - Joey and Chandler from Friends, Ashley and Nicky Platt from Coronation Street, bluff TV detectives Dalziel and Pascoe. The story content ranges from the sadistic (Mulder tying Krycek in knots) to the sensitive, with macho characters showing a level of vulnerability never allowed on screen.

It is no coincidence that the vast majority of character pairings come from shows with a tough guy element. If there's a common thread running through much of slash fiction, it's that women appear to find erotic appeal in emasculating TV hard men. Take the following example, from the LadySlash web-ring, which features slash coupling Starsky and Hutch:

"Is it worth risking our partnership? Our friendship?" asked Starsky.

"Yes," said Hutch.

"Hutch, don't. Don't cry. Please."

He felt a gentle hand brush at his cheek. "If this is a mistake..."

"It's not. Trust me."

"I don't want to lose you..."

"You're not gonna lose me. Close your eyes. Go on, close your eyes."

Something that felt like velvet brushed his ear. He shivered again, this time with raw emotion rather than chill. The velvet teaser moved slowly down his jaw, to nuzzle briefly at his neck before moving on... No woman had ever played with his nipples. Starsky was doing that. Licking them, covering them with little kisses until they hardened into tiny buds. If he's never done this before, how the hell can he do it so well?

This question seems a reasonable one to put to an author of the genre. Where on earth does the inspiration come from? Kitty Fisher, who works for the school library service by day, has been writing slash for eight years; her stories have appeared on the internet and in the Black Lace collection Wicked Words. "In a way it is easier for female writers to use male-on-male characters when writing about sex, particularly the type of sex that appears in slash fiction. There's a leaning to dark stories, non-consensual sex, dominance. By writing about men, you're distancing yourself."

So it's a guilt thing? "Well, we may have crossed the century but we are still tied to Victorian morality, even if we don't want to be. It's not acceptable for women to say they get turned on by sex and violence. But it's not just about that - there's an emphasis on humour and emotion which is lacking in a lot of mainstream erotic writing."

Fisher first stumbled upon slash in the pre-internet days when it existed only in obscure Star Trek fanzines. "I loved the use of characters I already knew, the subversion, the dark side to it. A reader knows the backstory; there are so many things actors do unconsciously on screen which fans can pick up on and twist to their own ends." She points out that for many writers, the appeal of slash is escapism. Many friends she has made on the scene work for the government, in management consultancy or teaching.

Elanor Summerton, who runs the Britslash website, says: "Analysing why I like slash is tricky. I've always assumed that if men like watching women together, women might enjoy the reverse. Women seem to prefer written erotica, with well-developed characters and more emotion. In fact, some of the best slash I've read has few sex scenes and is not explicit."

Another reason why many women are turning to the format is that the slash community encourages new writers. "It's very welcoming and supportive," explains R Olivia Brown who runs the RedRoses fanzine. "Discussion between writers abounds and it's not restricted by what's acceptable outside in the 'real' world. Here you can discuss grammar and penis size, often in the same email."

She believes slash is probably an attempt by women to take control of their sexuality but many writers may not be conscious they are addressing this. "The real appeal is that it allows us to explore a romantic relationship in which normal ideas about power and gender have no place because both characters are the same gender."

It's a nice idea but some cultural theorists suggest that slash, when deconstructed, mirrors nothing more daring than the format for Mills and Boon. "Like mass market romances written for women, the vast majority are first-time stories in which the hero and his ultimate sexual companion discover their physical attraction for the first time," says Camille Bacon-Smith in her book Enterprising Women, Television Fandom and the Creation of Popular Myth. To an extent this is true, though some of the longer-running series do move the action on - one recent X-Files story celebrates Mulder's pregnancy.

Perhaps another factor in the popularity of male/male pairings is that there aren't that many inspiring female characters to begin with. Another writer, who because of her job in the civil service will be identified only as Joram, takes this argument a stage further. "As a reader, slash for me is ideal fiction because I dislike female characters. They make me feel demeaned and ashamed because most tend to be two-dimensional. I focus on male characters because I like to lust over them."

So why not write heterosexual scenes? "There are a lot of strong male characters on TV that women would like to see show a vulnerable side," Joram explains. "What better way of doing that than by putting two guys in a romantic situation? Then we can make them vulnerable and hurt them emotionally to our heart's content, and there's no need to put a woman in there at all."

Privatisation has been the main policy option presented to transition countries since reforms began. Privatisation moved in three directions. Small privatisation of service units, shops, restaurants, etc; big privatisation of state owned enterprises, land and other assets; and the removal of tariffs and barriers to trade and the encouragement of private investment (including in service provision).

The scale and form of private ownership and the processes to achieve these reforms were rarely properly debated. The World Bank did not allow time for consensus to develop of what should be privately as opposed to publicly owned or run. The rush to privatise quickly was also motivated by a desire to introduce changes before opposition to those changes could be organised. In the 1996 World Development report, the World Bank refers to this as a "window of opportunity - a period of extraordinary politics. In which far reaching changes could be initiated with little dissent or opposition" .

The cost of privatisation:

Also in the 1996 World Development Report, the World Bank admits that it failed to anticipate the complications of privatisation : "Ukraine introduced a voucher privatisation programme .. but failed to carry it through effectively"; "The Russian programme is also an example of the serious tensions that often arise between political feasibility and economic desirability". "A particularly vexing question is who monitors the monitors . Supervision of financial agents is severely problematic in transition economies" . In fact in many transition countries the privatisation process was seen by the mass of unemployed and disenfranchised as a glorified theft of social assets, selling off the country assets to a privileged few. The voucher schemes, held up by the Bank as the most successful privatisation process, were plagued by corruption. In some countries individuals and families were left with small plots of land or livestock or tiny shares in enterprises which could not be turned into productive assets. Many failed to understand the concept of privatisation after up to 70 years of public ownership and thus they failed to manage their property or even secure their assets .

The production of inequality:

The way in which privatisation was carried out has produced considerable social injustice, corruption, unnecessary social stratification and uncompetitive markets dominated by monopolies, the opposite of what was intended. Alongside this has been a widespread disregard for the protection of labour and thus mass unemployment. A simultaneous dismantling of price controls and consumer subsidies also occurred. The net effect has been a phenomenal increase in poverty. UNDP data, based on government poverty lines suggest that in some Central Asian countries, 60-70 per cent of the population are living in poverty, up from 35-50 per cent before independence.

In the 1996 World Development Report, the Bank itself admits the importance of equity as the basis for stable society and economic growth; recent research corroborates this evidence: 'high levels of income-inequality limit the poverty reducing effects of growth high inequality countries will need to grow twice as fast as low inequality countries to halve poverty by 2015. This is not feasible'. Privatisation processes have served to institutionalise inequalities. The Bank admits that those with power: "have been able to turn their control rights into property rights through privatisation, leaving ordinary citizens with little. This has deepened public cynicism about reforms and undermined the legitimacy of the post reform economy" . In these institutionally dismantled economies there are insufficient mechanisms for redistribution of wealth. The descent into poverty has destroyed the middle class and left children more likely to be poor than the average person . The implications for inter-generational transmission of poverty are alarming.

In the process of privatisation existing institutions were often dismantled with little regard for what might take their place. The World Bank and IMF advocated slimmer government irrespective of function, often failing to recognise as valid any of the varied roles government played in pre-transition society. This also negated the possibility that government may need to play an increased role in some areas, especially if alternative institutions did not exist. Instead the Bank and other donors supported a complicated and questionable process of rapid institution building in the civil society sector.

The Bank is criticised for inadequate consideration of the complexity of the political implications of privatisation; the creation of a large dispossessed class through extraordinarily naive or simply inappropriate mechanisms to distribute assets; a failure to recognise components outside of legal institutions and banks which are necessary for entire populations to understand and trust privatisation; inadequate analysis of the complexity of privatisation, particularly of land and small asset privatisation; a failure to cope with the long term social costs of poverty and plan for phased unemployment or adequate social protection; and a failure to anticipate or understand the known social and environmental costs of privatisation in subsistence economies.

There has clearly so far been a failure to learn with the Bank and donors continuing to press for privatisation in all parts of the economy irrespective of known failures or local contexts. As a result, the privatisation of water assets is of huge concern for environmental reasons and in particular for marginalised groups.

Key concerns:

1. The introduction of user fees in health and education and in contexts where incomes have catastrophically declined is highly discriminatory. It is essential that social protection schemes work, but so far they have demonstrably failed. Citizens of transition countries feel they are a laboratory for economic theorists obsessed with private ownership . There are many forms of ownership and co-operation of which individual ownership is just one.

2. Blanket policy prescriptions regarding the role of the market and private ownership irrespective of local context has led to the inequality and poverty witnessed today in transition economies. The changing role of the public and private sector is not an inevitable progression towards more private and less public, but a more nuanced and constantly changing negotiation.

3. There are still countries entering or engaged with privatisation and other transition processes. It is imperative that the lessons learnt so far are constructively used and that alternative views of ownership and more open and democratic processes of decision making are allowed to emerge.

Broadband provider Videonet today launches its ADSL-based video-on-demand service HomeChoice in the London region.

Homechoice, which will be priced at £6 per month with a £40 one-off installation fee, promises to give access to 800 films, over 1,000 music videos, ITN news programmes and a raft of sports programming on demand via telephone lines.

The company has signed a number of high-profile content deals with studios including Warner Brothers, giving it access to programmes including BBC and Channel 4 shows, including The Sopranos, Friends and ER.

HomeChoice also offers banking and shopping services and fast internet access for a flat rate monthly fee of £20.

Videonet claims it is able to offer the ADSL service in most London postcodes. But Serafino Abate, a telecoms analyst at Ovum, pointed out that BT - from whom Videonet leases its service - says it can only offer ADSL to around 35% of the population.

Mr Abate said: "If the wholesaler [BT] can't offer ADSL throughout the country then I can't see how the retailer can offer it to most of the capital."

He also warned that providers like Videonet, which is paying more to BT for the lease of its local loop than the cost to the consumer, faces a major financial risk if it is not able to deliver the service to its subscribers. "It's very challenging for them and there's a high risk because they are not in control of the technology."

If ever mathematical proof was needed of Oprah Winfrey's importance to the nation, it was on obvious display this week. George W Bush jumped in the space of a few days from a 10-point deficit in the opinion polls to a 1% lead, and the only thing anyone could remember him doing was kissing the country's favourite chat-show hostess.

That may be a slight over-simplification. He appeared on another talkshow wearing a dark shirt which matched the one being worn by the host, Regis Philbin. People thought that was fun too, but they really liked the kiss. It seemed to have the same sort of tonic effect on Bush's political standing as Vice-President Al Gore's prolonged on-stage snog with his wife Tipper, at last month's party convention.

If anyone still doubted that the Oprah effect was truly in play in these elections, they only had to check out the breakdown of the polling figures. The greatest leap in Bush's support was among women, who make up the overwhelming majority of Oprah and Regis audiences, and who have proved to be an elusive electorate for republicans in general.

The television analysts said Bush won his poll surge just by looking relaxed and leaning forward, looking keen and engaged. But the kiss planted on the talkshow queen's cheek might have been the clincher. When Al Gore appeared on the Oprah show a few days earlier, he had offered his hand rather than his lips, earning a rebuke from his hostess. And the vice-president had sat back in his armchair and thrown his head back when he laughed, looking aloof.

The fact that the Oprah effect has thus been demonstrated under near-laboratory conditions (not much else was going on that might have spoiled the experiment) is likely to have a significant effect on future campaigns. The Oprah show, with its 7m viewers, is likely to become as important a stop along the way to the presidency as the presidential debates. There are likely to be Oprah trainers hired alongside the debate coaches, and they will specialise in body language - how to sit and how to kiss.

They will also teach the delicate art of confession, which has become an almost ritual need for a society steeped in the protocols of the talkshow and the soap opera. The confession must be offered at some apparent personal cost. It must draw a tear or at least a glassy eye.

Bush scored here. His eyes turned shiny after talking about his wife's difficult pregnancy, and stayed shiny through the ensuing commercial break. Gore, by remaining dry-eyed while talking about Tipper's struggle with depression, thus failed to fulfil the audience's expectations and we must conclude he suffered at the polls as a consequence.

But a confession is a double-edged dagger. A candidate will not wish to imply a lasting weakness. The fault he confesses must be something which he or she has overcome and which has only served to make him or her stronger. In Hollywood it is known as the narrative "arc". It is built into most of the characters in film or television dramas because it provides a satisfying mix of challenge and redemption.

Now, the electorate is expecting the same biographical curvature from the country's presidents as well. Bush scored particularly well here. He tells the well-used story of how he broke his long and deep relationship with alcohol the day after his 40th birthday in the wake of a raucous night out with friends - just about that time he found God.

Gore suffers because he lacks this sort of an arc. His progression from senator's son to congressman to senator to vice-president has been tediously linear. Straight lines do not play well in the movies, and in the Age of Oprah they make for bad politics too.

Twelve-year-old Aisling McCabe had a day off school this week. She wasn't sick. Instead, she was doing vital work trying to help catch shopkeepers illegally selling harmful goods to children.

She is one of hundreds of young people recruited to help trading standards officers - the people responsible for enforcing the rules restricting the sale of such things as cigarettes, alcohol and gas lighter refills. The government supports the idea. Just this month it published new targets encouraging the undercover scheme against shopkeepers who "flout the laws" on under-age sales.

Is it safe as an undercover agent?

"I felt scared at first," says Aisling, "but I got used to it. We visited 18 shops and on the way to each one I was told what to ask for and reminded not to look at the officer coming in with me."

There are strict rules protecting children out on such patrols. They are never alone. Officers go into the shops with them so that later they can be a witness. Children are not expected to give evidence in court. And before the trading standards people pounce, there is time for the child to leave the shop. Also, the visits take place well away from the child's area.

According to Aisling, the only problem she had was being told off by a shopkeeper when she asked for cigarettes: "that was horrible, but it was good too - at least she wasn't prepared to let me have them."

Is it fair to "entrap" shop-keepers?

It isn't entrapment, say trading standards officers. It is always a follow-up to local information campaigns during which shop-owners are warned that they may be receiving such visits. Also, the children are not allowed to lie. If challenged, they must give their true age.

The only way to prosecute people breaking these trading laws is to catch them red-handed. A survey published last October showed that in areas ranging from the London borough of Bromley, to Wolverhampton and the Isle of White, children bought restricted goods in six out of 10 shops.

Have children been doing this investigative work for a long time?

Yes, for many years in some areas. But the big increase has been since 1991, when the law was tightened to stop sales of cigarettes to people actually under 16. Before that the law covered sales to those "apparently" under 16. Now it is the responsibility of the shop owner to apply a "No proof of age, no sale" policy with restricted items. To help them, some councils, such as Essex, are distributing proof of age cards to students.

What penalties do shop-keepers face if they break the rules?

The maximum fine is £2,000. Usually the penalty for a first offence is about £200-£300. What hurts is the bad publicity shops receive in local newspapers when prosecuted.

Often the shop-owners know the rules, but it is their staff, sometimes not much older than the customers themselves, who fail to apply them. Not that this is a defence.

Is the policy of using young people effective as a deterrent?

Yes. In Liverpool the trading standards have been working with children on undercover operations since 1988 and have seen illegal sales fall dramatically. At the start, they occurred on 85% of visits, but now on just 5%. However, not all local authorities have enough officers to mount these operations.

Do these investigations really help protect young people?

It is essential to keep these items away from children, so anything that makes them harder to buy is worthwhile. Sniffing glue or lighter gas can be lethal, and the nicotine in cigarettes is more addictive than cocaine and heroin. Of course, while the children working with trading standards are not allowed to wear make-up or lie, there is nothing to stop others disguising their ages.

What do the children working undercover get out of this work?

"I feel strongly about it," says Aisling. "Children a bit older than me are getting into smoking and it can kill. It was exciting going undercover and the officers bought me sweets and magazines in every shop."

The Sydney Olympic games do not just represent the pinnacle of sporting achievement; they are also a showcase for cutting-edge science and technology. When the modern Olympics commenced in Athens in 1896, the results were not recorded in detail. The stopwatch and camera were first used at the 1932 Olympics in Los Angeles. With so little to choose between performances today, many are increasingly looking to technology to give them the edge. A 1% improvement can make the difference between success and failure and there is now almost no aspect of performance where science does not play a prominent role.

Training

All top athletes are constantly monitored to ensure they can produce their peak performances on the critical occasion. Blood tests are routinely performed to check that the optimum levels of amino acids are present, cardiographs are used to monitor heart rates to allow athletes to train to their optimum aerobic potential and new training techniques have been devised by sports scientists that both prevent injury and reduce the recovery time between workouts.

Technology

These days, technology doesn't just have the capacity to enhance performance, it can also change the way sports are played. Even swimming, one of the most natural of events, has been affected. Pools are now designed to minimise wave interference and to provide greater grip for kick turns off the wall at each end. The freestyle stroke has also changed from the conventional straight-arm action to a more efficient "S" motion that enables swimmers to move towards water that has not already been pushed backwards by the initial phase of the stroke, thereby reducing drag and increasing buoyancy. Technology is also being used to set limits on performance. Distances in the javelin were increasing by such large amounts in the 1980s, there were fears that throwers might become a danger to spectators and other athletes; the weight distribution of the javelin has now been redesigned to shorten flight times and distance and to put greater emphasis on the skill and technique of the thrower.

Clothing

One of the most obvious signs of technological advances has been the changes in clothing. Every sport now has its own footwear; among the latest running shoes for track and field athletes at Sydney are z-spikes and hover shoes. Marathon runners are after the perfect singlet that will allow them to lose sweat most efficiently, while sprinters wear all-in-one aerodynamic space suits. These don't just cut drag; they can also suppress muscle vibration and save energy. Why so sceptical? Because it's seven days a week, 12 hours a day - except Sunday.

What do licensees do? Run any of the 60,000 pubs in the UK, small and large, traditional and themed, most serving food of some description.

Busy life. Not half. Apart from serving, we're keeping accounts, controlling stock, buying in drink, food and other goods, and recruiting, training and supervising the staff. Many licensees do the cooking themselves and are responsible for the health and safety of staff and customers and deal with any security issues.

Are there different sorts of licensee? Yeah: managers, tenants or freetraders. Managers are salaried employees of a pub's owners. Tenants run pubs leased to them by the owners. Freetraders own the pubs they run and are independent.

What skills does the job need? It is essential to get on well with all kinds of people, to be outgoing with good conversational and listening skills.

Oh real... Oy! Don't interrupt. Licensees must be able to deal with any trouble in the pub and have good management skills for training and motivating staff. Numeracy and business skills are essential for cash-handling, accounts, stock control, buying, pricing etc. Licensees must be able to learn and follow the legal requirements of their business concerning licensing, food and health and safety.

Any academic requirements? No. Personal qualities are more important. Previous business experience is desirable and some bar work experience is helpful. Traditionally it has been seen as a job for couples, but singletons are increasingly running pubs. You have to be 18 to serve behind a bar, but 25 is often seen as a realistic lower age limit for a licensee.

Other qualifications? Sure. Relevant ones include NVQs 1 and 2 in catering and hospitality; On-licensed premises supervisory management, level 3 and 4 and the British Institute of Innkeeping (BII) certificate of induction. There's even a degree in licensed retail management at the University of Wolverhampton.

It's that time of the year again - that "Oh no, I've got to get my future plans sorted out in the next 10 minutes!" time, when prospectuses, rough drafts of personal statements and the like start flying about careers rooms around the country, in an ever-increasing frenzy as the autumn term progresses.

Recent discussions about a six-term year with exams in April, results in July and a post-qualifications applications system for higher education remain in the realms of fantasy.

Now is the time to get your act together (no more phoning a friend or asking the audience), do the research you should have done last term and get that higher education application sent off as soon as possible. Even though it's 12 months before you'll start (maybe 24 if you are planning a gap year) Ucas forms must be completed soon.

If you are an Oxbridge candidate or a potential medic, vet or dentist then the deadline is fast approaching - October 15. For everyone else the deadline is later - December 15 - but schools and colleges will have their own deadlines much earlier than this and in any case it pays to get your form in early. If it is with Ucas in October there's a good chance you will have heard from most of your choices by the end of this year and this is likely to provide good motivation for the rest of the academic year's studies.

What are the main issues you need to address? Your choice of course and university matters most, after you've analysed exactly why you want to go in the first place.

The majority of the evidence available suggests that a successful higher education experience is a positive thing in a variety of respects, not the least of which are the personal ones of independence, freedom, responsibility and making new friends. Many will think about career prospects, whether it be in terms of status, salary, job satisfaction or a mixture of the three. Here there is no doubt that a degree, whilst not guaranteeing anything, is going to help in the job market and gives an enormous advantage over a non-graduate. Recent reports suggest that the average starting salary for a graduate is up 4% to £18,330 this year, with the best paid jobs in legal services.

Many professions are all graduate entry, others are becoming so. For some you will need a specific vocational degree, for others a degree in any discipline will suffice. Around 40-50% of all graduate employers are not concerned with your degree subject. They focus on other qualities you will have gained from your time at university. These include communication skills, problem-solving and decision-making skills, self-confidence, adaptability and flexibility and the ability to work under pressure.

How do you choose what to study when all your brain will come up with is a blank whenever you think about it? For some, probably the minority, this is a straightforward issue. One of your A-levels interests you and you want to take it to a higher level. Others may have a particular career in mind and need to follow a specific degree - medicine for doctors, pharmacy for pharmacists, golf course management for golf course managers etc.

For the rest it isn't such an easy decision - but it is worth taking some time to get right. Your choice does not have to be related to a career; rather it should be something you'll really enjoy studying otherwise you'll drop out of uni sooner rather than later. This means reading and research - both time-consuming but essential if you are to make a sensible choice.

Exploring the possibilities will open your mind to the options of taking a joint degree (two subjects of equal weight) or a combined or modular degree (where the subject combinations are even broader). There are also many new subjects available at degree level that are not possible at A-level. A cautionary note - don't mix up your subject choices too broadly (for example three physics plus three English probably equals six rejections).

There are now over 300 different institutions in the Ucas system and choosing six between Aberdeen and Ystrad Mynach (there are no Zs yet!) can be a big task. Decide on your criteria. Are you going to stay at home? If you are planning to go away, how far do want to go? New university or old/traditional? Campus or town/city centre?

Checking required grades with your predicted grades is part of all this so find out both - neither are state secrets! Whilst all these are important and are bound to exercise your mind, perhaps the most crucial issue is course content. If this isn't right when you start it does not matter how happy you are with your location, you'll struggle very quickly. Finance (or lack of it) will also play a major role in your decision, especially if you do decide to study away from home. Stories of massive debts on graduation are not total fiction - in the short and medium term money is likely to be tight, but in the long term the financial and other advantages of higher education definitely outweigh the disadvantages.

It's not too late to come up with an informed and well-thought-out application even if you are squeezing nine months' research into nine days. Use the time fully and take advice from those you respect. This could be the first stage towards the best years of your life.

Ucas are now encouraging students to apply via the electronic application system - EAS. This year 37,000 did so and the number is expected to double for the 2001 round and eventually overtake paper applications. It is a quick way of filling in your Ucas form on computer - the programme corrects mistakes automatically and avoids the use of dozens of practice forms. The personal statement can be cut and pasted on and print preview allows you to see your final form the way the universities will see it. Once it arrives at Ucas, there is a good chance it will be processed more quickly than a paper form - even in as little as three days.

The downside is that there have been some hiccups in the system's early development and not all schools, colleges or careers centres can use it yet. Ucas insist problems with their system not running on RM computers have now been eliminated and it will work on any PC, though not on Macs. You cannot apply direct to Ucas using EAS. You must apply through your school, college or careers centre. There they will check the form, attach the reference and send it to Ucas. Ucas intend to launch an internet version in 2002.

Oxford university will review its marketing and recruitment to attract more applicants from further education colleges, but it won't dilute its rigorous academic entry criteria.

Candidates will still have to get three grade As at A-levels, it was made clear to college principals attending a conference on admissions to the university from the sector.

For the foreseeable future, Oxford won't be accepting other qualifications as substitutes for three As to achieve the minimum 30-point tariff.

Summer schools at Oxford run exclusively for further education students were among a package of proposals to stimulate more interest in the sector and remove widespread prejudice there against the university.

These also included sabbatical terms spent by further education tutors at the university, closer links between dons and further education tutors, and much more contact between Oxford students and prospective applicants from the sector.

Clarity and openness were hallmarks of what both sides unanimously agreed was a frank, illuminating and encouraging exercise.

"I think they were listening very very carefully to what we have to say," said Sue Dutton, deputy chair of the Association of Colleges.

Mansfield College, which hosted the one-day event, is spearheading a consortium of seven Oxford colleges which share the common aim of targeting the further education sector to stimulate more applications from it.

Mansfield's principal, Professor David Marquand, reiterated what he made clear in Guardian Further last week, that for too long the numbers of further education students trying for Oxford had been far too low.

Last year 459 candidates from the sector applied to Oxford. There were 4,373 applications from state schools and 3,426 from independent schools.

Of the further education applicants 30% got in compared with a 38% overall success rate. Only 4% of "mature" applicants - aged over 21 - were successful. The further education sector caters for huge numbers of students in this age group.

The possibility of increasing the numbers of mature undergraduate students at Oxford will be the focus of a project at Harris Manchester College, one of the consortium of seven. Harris Manchester bills itself as the only university college in the country which solely admits mature students to study full-time for a first degree.

Perhaps the most useful part of the day for the principals and managers from general further education and sixth-form colleges was an explanation of the Oxford admissions procedure by Edwin Peel, law and admissions tutor at Keble College.

He said the trickiest task facing admissions tutors was choosing between candidates who generally had exclusively A* and A GCSE scores and were predicted to get three As at A-level. He said candidates' personal statement and referees' assessments were scrutinised very carefully. And despite the mystique surrounding the Oxford interview, it was largely focused on the subject the candidate wanted to study. A number of mock interviews with students were staged to illustrate the point.

Offers will remain three grade As in the form of A2s, not the new AS qualification, which, under the new Curriculum 2000, students will achieve in the first year of a typical two-year A-level course.

"We are an academic university. We think that three As at A2 is the academic benchmark for assessing candidates," he said. "We will certainly take into account other qualifications."

Ann Limb, principal of Cambridge Regional College, said afterwards: "It was great, fantastic."

She had no problems with the academic entry requirement.

"Further education realises that Oxford represents excellence and we want our students associated with that excellence."

Probably the first economic migrants to visit Britain were the Romans - and a very good job they did when they arrived here, bringing much needed engineering skills with them.

They gave us good roads, town planning and a much needed public sanitation system. The Romans were, in truth, the first visitors to fill what we today call the skills gap.

So as interesting as Barbara Roche's views are on solving our current skills gap by allowing more highly skilled economic migrants in to Britain, they also prove, in the words of an old newspaperman, there is nothing new under the sun.

And, while Mrs Roche's views are a contribution to the skills gap debate, they are obviously not the solution. As so often has been the case in the past, only we, the British people, government, industry and educationalists, can solve the persistent conundrum: "Why do our main competitors in Germany, France and America all train their people better than we do?"

David Blunkett is the latest education secretary to try to improve our post-16 vocational training and he will outline his detailed plans in full at the Labour Party Conference in Brighton this week.

We greatly welcome his commitment to attacking the inadequacies of vocational training for school-leavers. For too long Britain has focused its educational resources on the academic elite who have gone on to gain the glittering prizes at our world-renowned universities.

Now we have an Education Secretary who has climbed to the top via the Gas Board and long hours of evening study at further education colleges, and who wants to do something for all those young people who regard Oxford merely as the town where Inspector Morse drives around in an old Jaguar.

Our colleagues in the Confederation of British Industry and the British Chambers of Commerce condemned Mr Blunkett's proposed overhaul of apprenticeships as "seriously flawed". I believe that is too strong. The Education Secretary should score 10 out of 10 for effort and determination, but perhaps only 7 out of 10 for content.

The Confederation of British Industry and British Chambers of Commerce complain that his £6bn plan for 100,000 apprenticeships for 16- and 17-year-olds is too prescriptive, especially the fixed minimum time-serving and specifying where the training should take place, particularly in local further education colleges. They want flexibility in training. They do not want Whitehall telling them how long or where they should train their employees.

Coming from an engineering background, where five-year apprenticeships used to be the norm, I do not have such a problem with prescribed minimum time-serving. My industry is now down to three-year apprenticeships, which I believe is about correct, but I can see why the service sector believes that even that may be too long for training in such areas as office skills.

My main area of concern in what Mr Blunkett is proposing is the quality of applicants that will benefit from the new scheme when it is fully up and running. The Guardian reported last month, in an unsourced story, that he will offer apprenticeships to over 100,000 16- and 17-year-olds who drop out of work or school.

I was pleased to see in recent interview that Mr Blunkett was careful to avoid such exaggerated claims. But even such claims from his advisers and spin doctors send out the wrong message. This policy is not directly about tackling poverty and social exclusion. It should not be viewed or used as some form or extension of New Deal. It is not even primarily about taking young people off the unemployment register.

It is about giving school-leavers proper qualifications and training and providing a proper vocational ladder of qualifications that stands equal to the existing academic ladder of qualifications.

It means that the brightest and best of our 16-year-olds can choose to take up an engineering apprenticeship rather than stay on at school, because that is the regular choice offered by their careers master. Why shouldn't a bright youngster choose to leave and learn to build world-beating McLaren Formula One cars in Woking rather than staying on into the sixth form?

For far too long Britain's brightest and best have regarded trade as a dirty word. We welcome David Blunkett's efforts to end that elitist view.

A national university for the newly independent territory of East Timor could be open for business as early as next month, according to the man most widely expected to become the first elected leader of the world's youngest state.

The guerrilla-turned-statesman Xanana Gusmão, until last September a political prisoner in the Indonesian capital and now one of the key players in the effort to rebuild East Timor, said the as yet unnamed institution would be operating "only in minimal conditions", with at least another three years needed to constitute its curricula, teaching resources and overall structure.

The transitional government cabinet in Dili, which comprises four East Timorese and four international ministers, has agreed to submit a plan to transfer budgetary funds to support the opening of the University of East Timor on a provisional basis next month. An earlier plan for Jesuit educators to establish a private university in the largely Roman Catholic territory has been placed on hold.

Filomeo Jacob, the cabinet minister responsible for social affairs, has said the university will need to admit up to 4,500 students in its first intake. His government has appealed to international donors to assist with up to $2m in startup costs.

Its language of instruction - a contentious issue among educators working on the half-island - will probably be Portuguese, although English and Indonesian are also being considered.

During the decades of Indonesian occupation of the one-time Portuguese colony, which lasted from 1975 until last year, the Portuguese language was banned in public life, with the result being that a majority of today's young Timorese are more fluent in the Indonesian tongue.

"We have so many priorities in education right now," Gusmão said, "and the first ones have had to be for the schools."

Gusmão was in the South Pacific visiting Timorese postgraduates at New Zealand's Massey University. Those Timorese postgraduates not currently studying in New Zealand are at universities either in Australia or Japan - the latter enjoying longstanding educational links with Portugal - with another 4,000 enrolled at Indonesian campuses on Java, their attendance dating back to be fore last September's politically inspired mayhem in East Timor.

Much of the half-island's already frail infrastructure was destroyed late last year after more than 80% of the island's 850,000 inhabitants used a historic referendum to choose independence from Indonesia. The plebiscite sparked weeks of violent unrest with hundreds, possibly thousands, of locals killed by militia forces loyal to Jakarta. Tracts of the capital, Dili, were razed by roaming gangs of street toughs.

For administrative purposes, including education, the fledgling nation is now being run by the United Nations, ahead of local elections to be held by 2002.

Western well-wishers, however, rather than military belligerents from nearby Indonesia, could yet prove to be the biggest future obstacle to the successful establishment of the university, said Gusmão, mentioning the widely publicised case of Jarat Chopra, a lecturer in international law at Brown University in Rhode Island in the US, who abruptly quit Dili just four months into a two-year stint with the territory's UN administrators.

Before his departure, Chopra accused the UN bureaucrats of putting the territory's future second to their own careers in a way that bordered "on criminal negligence".

In the three months since then, said Gusmão, "we have tried - with some success, I believe - to persuade the UN that they must involve everyone in their work." But it isn't just the UN that has had to change, he added. "It's visiting academics, too."

With their rich-world viewpoints and training, foreign scholars continued to be a mixed blessing for materially impoverished East Timor, he said. "They would do better not to come to us with a high sense of international standards, which are very good so far as they go, but don't really fit in with the reality of what is happening in East Timor. We can all probably work better if we work together, not from the sky down but from the ground up.

"I'm not saying that they're not very important to us - they are," he continued. "But some academics, we've come to feel, are not always coming to us with a sufficient grasp of our reality, and that is becoming more of a problem for us, and the nation we are creating."

Not so long ago, education was one of the sleepiest branches of the law. "From 1907 until 1989 - that's 82 years - there were only 20 cases that could be genuinely claimed as dealing with education," says John Friel, a leading barrister in the field.

Now everyone is having a pop at schools and local authorities, and hiring lawyers to juice up their claims: burnt-out teachers; former pupils who feel their schools failed them; parents who believe their child's special needs are not being met; parents of bullied children; even parents whose child simply didn't get into their school of choice. And, increasingly, those parents not actually going so far as the High Court are trundling along to appeals with a brief or solicitor in tow in the hope that legal muscle will scare a good result for them.

League tables, Ofsted inspections and a sharpening of everyone's sense of being consumers and not mute recipients have changed the landscape.

The number of appeals by parents against primary and secondary schools that did not admit their children rose from 77,000 in 1997-98 to 85,900 the following year. The figure for the latest school year is expected to show another leap to 95,000.

At the same time, lawyers have found much to play with among the endless flow of legislation. Every new statute creates work for the legal profession, and since 1979, education acts have appeared at the rate of almost one a year. Latterly the acts have given education secretaries of state huge scope for issuing subsequent statutory instruments - orders and regulations filling in details. Of the 4,000 to 5,000 statutory instruments published annually by government, up to 200 concern education.

In response to this burgeoning legislation, the Education Law Association (Elas) was set up 10 years ago to provide guidance to its membership of lawyers and educational managers. For a few years it remained an obscure body, but now it receives five inquiries a day from parents.

"Ten years ago you would have been hard put to find a lawyer who specialised in education," says Richard Clutterbuck, of Luton University, who produces the journal Education Law Monitor. Now, you can hardly move for them. Next month, London will host two conferences for them: one, chaired by Clutterbuck, is the Law Society's education law conference; the other focuses on special educational needs.

And as the education "consumers" become more reliant on legal muscle, so, too, do the education "providers". Education matters would once have been a minor part of a municipal lawyer's duties; not any more. Jack Rabinowicz, partner at Teacher Stern Selby, a London firm, says: "Local authorities now have a nominated lawyer in their legal department who's their education specialist."

The action they face from parents comes in three categories: special needs, admissions and exclusions.

The 1994 Code of Practice for special educational needs, which insisted that parents should be consulted, jolted them into starting to challenge decisions, says Clutterbuck.

Since then there had been an incremental broadening of the definition of need, he says. The Court of Appeal earlier this year ruled that a tetraplegic child needed physiotherapy to get education. Unlike health services, which are rationed, educational services cannot be. Education authorities have used every procedural device to minimise numbers of children officially "statemented" for special provision and more parents have sought to challenge them.

The proportion of special needs tribunal hearings - where parents appeal against decisions - to which parents are bringing lawyers is steadily rising. In 1997/98 only one in 10 parents was legally represented at the 1,200 or so cases heard each year. Last year it was one in five.

Then, less than two months ago, a landmark House of Lords ruling upped the ante still further. Pamela Phelps, 26, was awarded £45,650 damages for the west London borough of Hillingdon's failure to diagnose her dyslexia. This decision has had a predictable consequence: a deluge of calls to solicitors.

Schools' admissions decisions where, typically, parents can't get children into their preferred secondaries because they are already full, have been more difficult to overturn since the 1998 Schools Standards and Framework act, but that hasn't stopped parents bringing lawyers in. It's cheaper to hire a lawyer than move house, says Clutterbuck, and "it salves their conscience. Parents want to feel they've done their best for their child and if that means getting lawyers to fight appeals, they'll do it."

Similarly, parents are increasingly seeking judicial review when their appeals about excluded children are turned down. Conversely, when heads readmit a child excluded for bullying, parents of the victims are starting to seek judicial review.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, regrets that the presence of unstable kids, some reinstated after exclusion, has driven more teachers, including those who have been injured, to seek advice from their union lawyers about litigation. The landmark case came when a teacher, Hazel Spence-Young, won £85,000 for a neck injury sustained in an assault by a pupil.

John Friel rejects the notion that lawyers have been flooding into education as the pinch on legal aid has shrunk other activity. Some of his colleagues have pursued the speciality after fighting for their own children's needs. "There are probably no more than 50 barristers with regular litigation experience in education."

But what about 20 years ago? Probably none, he admits.
