So rap the children from St Paulinus C of E Primary School in Crayford, Kent, who last week received the Millennium Marque from the Tidy Britain Group for their environmental work - the only school to be so honoured.

The school is blessed with a little wooded area, and until about seven years ago this was just used as a short-cut to get to the playing field. A group of parents cleared away the rubbish from this overgrown and neglected corner of the grounds and marked out a proper pathway. That was the beginning of a sustainability project that has gone from strength to strength.

On entering the school there is a wall covered with certificates - from Bexley in Bloom through to the prestigious Eco-Schools Award, evidence of the school's commitment towards green issues.

The grounds are not huge, but with the well-planned layout they give the impression that a small child could wander for hours round ponds and through wooded secret gardens, or just sit and watch the birds and butterflies. Every aspect of the school is reviewed by the pupils for its environmental impact in order to identify targets for action and improvement.

A plan is then drawn up involving the children, teachers, parents and local community, which is constantly monitored and evaluated. Different groups have responsibility for particular tasks: in the bird garden, where feeders of every shape and size are hung, the children in year six are responsible for watering the flowers, but the reception class fills the birdbath. This year reception have planted a hazel walk and bower, which, by the time they leave the school, will have grown into another established feature of the grounds.

Projects are designed with this aim in mind, and the children have a sense of shared ownership in the school. Many still visit after they have left, wanting not just to check on how their own work has matured, but to see what the new kids have been up to. They also often initiate sustainability projects in their secondary schools.

Environmental issues are integrated into the national curriculum, touching every subject. A regular science class feature is pond dipping - taking a jar of pond water and examining it and learning about the contents. The butterfly garden is planted and cared for by the children. On the wall are the descriptions and models of the different butterflies so that they can be easily identified.

The pupils have carried out projects on waste recycling and have a policy of using both sides of the paper; the saving of energy is another high priority, with projects to design posters to remind each other to switch off the lights. The use, recycling and waste of water have found their way into maths and geography. And the environment is used in all areas of literacy, even if it is just sitting in the garden listening to a story.

The grounds are treated as another classroom, to be appreciated all year round, not just in the summer. Outside of school hours are the Twitchers club and the Greenfingers club, the latter run by a parent whose children have now left St Paulinus - it isn't just the pupils who find it hard to leave.

The school is very open and shares its grounds with the community and particularly with a nearby special needs school. With this in mind, the woodchip paths in the wood are wide enough to accommodate a wheelchair. Again it is the pupils' responsibility to maintain the paths, making sure they are accessible.

The local business community is also involved, and in amongst the labels for buddleia and lavender are plaques commemorating donations from Woolwich plc and benches from Sainsbury's and Barclays.

The Eco-Schools project aims to bring up young people to act responsibly, and acknowledge what is happening in their environment - and in turn to influence their parents and peers. Bexley council wants to encourage positive citizens. The impact across the whole school has been positive, with academic results giving as much pleasure to the parents as the green fingers give to the pupils.

The children at St Paulinus are proud of their achievements and Nicola and Vicki from year six, members of the eco-committee, needed no prompting to offer a guided tour, even in torrential rain. There was no way the eco-rap was not going to be performed for a visitor. The eco- committee is made up of pupils, teachers, governors and parents, but the children have a major input and it is another way they can express their views and know that their ideas are valued and taken into account.

The various projects have resulted in financial savings for the school as the managing of utilities has come under the eco-committee's eagle eye and a policy of environmental purchasing has been agreed.

New headteacher Adam Higgins has already been well briefed on the current projects, which include a raised viewing platform and a plan for the edge of the playground. He is beginning to sound like his pupils.

Slobodan Milosevic, struggling to retain his grip on the Yugoslav presidency, sought yesterday to force a second round runoff in the face of a deafening chorus of domestic and international calls for him to relinquish power.

All unofficial polls - except for those carried out by Mr Milosevic's Socialist party and some of its allies - put him more than 20% behind his main challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, who has managed to unite a fractured opposition. Mr Milosevic, cornered, is now fighting for time.

Mr Kostunica, 56, a law professor, claimed victory in Sunday's ballot and demanded that the state election commission release the official count: "This is a peoples' victory," he declared. "We will defend our victory by peaceful means and we will protest for as long as it takes."

As the commission delayed the announcement of the results, both sides issued widely conflicting unofficial results. The Democratic Opposition of Serbia claimed that with the votes counted at 60% of polling stations, Mr Kostunica was leading on 55.31%, against to Mr Milosevic's 34.19%.

But Gorica Gajevic, the general secretary of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party, said that with 37 % of the ballots counted, the president was ahead, on 45 % to Mr Kostunica's 40%."This result gives us optimism that we can win in the first round," he added.

There was no word from Mr Milosevic himself, and fears persisted that the authorities would resort to violence to retain their grip on power.

Western countries piled the pressure on the Yugoslav leader to accept defeat. Germany, Britain, Italy, France and the European Union all declared that Mr Milosevic had lost in Sunday's vote. The US said it doubted Mr Milosevic could make any "credible claim of victory".

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "Today Milosevic is a beaten, broken-backed president. My message to him today is, be honest with your people. Get out of the way and let Serbia get out of the prison you have turned it into."

The fightback began yesterday afternoon at a press conference for domestic consumption, in which Mr Gajevic insisted that Mr Milosevic had taken the first round of the election but that the margin was small, so he would fight a second round in a fortnight to give him absolute victory.

But even former Milosevic allies such as the ultranationalist Radical party agree that he has lost. Analysts said Mr Milosevic's camp was divided between those advising him to declare an outright victory and those saying he should play for time. Even a runoff would represent a loss of face.

Milos Aligridoc, a member of the opposition said yesterday: "[A runoff] would mean absolute humiliation for him and he is not a man who likes to be humiliated ."

Belgrade was calm yesterday but pressure is beginning to mount against the business people involved with the rul ing party, who have long controlled the wealthy shopping streets and the black market in cigarettes, petrol and whisky.

The opposition was out on the streets of Belgrade again last night, celebrating victory. Everywhere people are discussing Mr Milosevic's fate.

"I go for the Ceaucescu option myself,"said one housewife. "Although, I think he will be killed by someone inside his own circle who wants to become a hero of the Serbian people."

The state election commission was locked out of its office in the federal parliament building yesterday, as it has been since Sunday night, effectively suspending the official count. Police are tracing the last, bizarre movements of an army deserter and former mercenary in Bosnia, who was shot dead after confronting police marksmen with a camouflaged air rifle in the grounds of a secure psychiatric hospital.

The police complaints authority launched an investigation into the tragedy yesterday after the man had briefly held up a police station late on Sunday night and then demanded to see a woman hospital worker.

He was named yesterday as Kirk Davies, 30, who was jailed three years ago for attacking his father. The court heard that Davies had hero-worshipped his father until discovering that he was an ex-army lorry driver rather than the SAS veteran of Cambodia he had pretended to be.

Davies appeared suddenly at Selby police station in West Yorkshire on Sunday evening, dressed entirely in black and with a gun draped in camouflage netting which he aimed at the duty sergeant.

Police said yesterday that he ran off without firing the gun, but turned up an hour later at Newton Lodge secure hospital in Wakefield, 20 miles away, still brandishing the weapon. He asked for the woman, who works in another hospital nearby, which he appeared to be making for when police arrived.

Assistant Chief Constable Andy Brown said Davies was challenged but refused to surrender the gun and was followed to a patch of woodland where he was challenged again and then shot. He did not fire at police and the gun was found to be an air rifle when paramedics moved in to take him to Pinderfields hospital, Wakefield, where he died soon after midnight.

Mr Brown said: "These are tragic circumstances and we have been in contact with Mr Davies's family and we offer our sympathy and condolences to them."

Detectives have found no link between Davies and Newton Lodge, which houses a number of seriously disturbed patients, and believe that he mistook the building for the hospital where the unnamed woman works. He threatened terrified staff with his gun after they insisted that he had got the wrong hospital.

Neighbours in Selby and the nearby village of Burn, where Davies had shared a council house with a girlfriend and her two-year-old son, said he had been unpredictable and a victim of "black moods" apparently connected to atrocities seen in the Balkans. Police were called regularly to domestic disputes at the house in St Leonard's Avenue, Selby, according to local residents, and Davies made regular references to his work as a sniper for the Croatians.

He joined the Duke of Wellington's Regiment at 19, but deserted out of boredom, in spite of seeing action briefly in Northern Ireland. He then served as a mercenary sniper in Bosnia, allegedly killing 46 Serbian soldiers, according to his defence barrister at the 1997 trial for assaulting his father.

Robert Collins, representing Davies at the appeal court in York, said that the young deserter had been "involved in the very worst of the fighting and atrocities, seeing sights which no one would even wish to think about".

He told Recorder Aidan Marron QC: "He can still see the faces of the Serbs he killed, and is now terrified of battles, having seen so many people dead."

Davies's sentence was reduced from nine months' jail to probation. After hearing that his nightmares had been compounded by bitter disillusion with his father's lies, Recorder Marron told him: "There is a need to address your problem and we wish you well."

After the incident, Davies was moody and withdrawn according to Selby newsagent John Watson, 60, who listened to his stories of the Balkans as Davies drifted through a succession of local jobs as nightclub doorman, labourer and security guard.

Mr Watson said Davies had once taken an overdose of painkillers and added: "He suffered from what seemed like blackouts when he didn't appear to know what he was doing."

Ian Murray, landlord of the Wheatsheaf in Burn, said that Davies had been quiet, but a member of the pub's pool team with his own cue called Excalibur. He said: "He was a very competitive lad and he always liked to win but he never gave the impression of being a Rambo type."

The investigation into missing embryos at two fertility clinics took a new twist last night when one of the hospitals involved confirmed that it was looking into possible financial irregularities in connection with the scientist at the centre of the scandal.

The investigation is said to be focusing on whether Paul Fielding, an embryologist who worked for both North Hamp shire Hospitals NHS Trust in Basingstoke and the privately run Hampshire Clinic, submitted claims for IVF treatment he never actually carried out. This might explain why discrepancies have emerged between patient records and stored embryos.

As 39 women treated at the hospitals where frozen embryos have gone missing were offered free DNA tests to prove their babies are their own, Mr Fielding's employer, the NHS trust, confirmed that its inquiry had widened to examine "any question of financial irregularities" in relation to his work involving the recording and storage of embryos.

Until his suspension Mr Fielding had held the position at the NHS trust for about 10 years. He was contracted out to work for the private Hampshire Clinic until two months ago, when it appointed its own embryologist.

Last night Mr Fielding's home in Whitchurch was deserted and neighbours said they had not seen him or his wifeand two young sons since the scandal broke on Thursday.

A Hampshire Clinic spokeswoman, Carole Friend, said they had been unable to contact Mr Fielding and were keen to speak to him.

Strict guidelines laid down by the Human Fertility and Embryology Authority mean that only a named embryologist can freeze and store em bryos and keep records of these operations. Seeing patients and harvesting eggs cis only carried out by a medical specialist.

Ms Friend added: "It looks like we are dealing with a case of poor record-keeping. It seems to be issues more about carelessness, not completing processes and never freezing embryos when he said he did."

She confirmed that the clinic would consider offering free treatment to women whose fertility treatment has been suspended because of errors in their patient records relating to their stored embryos. In addition, DNA tests are being offered, although she claimed there was "categorically no possibility" women had been given the wrong embryos.

The fact that some patients undergoing IVF treatment are distressed is of particular concern because it has a high failure rate and patients are advised to avoid stress.

The two clinics are also bracing themselves for potential group legal action from patients whose embryos may have been lost or whose treatment has been disrupted.

The situation came to light three weeks ago when staff were unable to find the frozen embryos of a patient due to undergo IVF treatment. As a result an audit was carried out at the assisted conception units at both the hospital and the clinic and it was found that nine containers were missing and other records appeared inconsistent.

Last night Emma Holt, a specialist in clinical negligence with the Manchester law firm Pannone and Partners said couples whose embryos went missing may be able to bring a case for the loss of a chance of conceiving in respect of that embryo and the ordeal of having to repeat IVF treatment.

Health and safety laws covering work and transport are to be introduced for the first time in quarter of a century, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced at the Labour party conference yesterday.

The shake-up will see directors and companies being held legally responsible for accidents in the workplace and prison sentences being imposed for the majority of health and safety offences - instead of the minority.

Corporate manslaughter could be brought in and fines are expected to be linked to a company's turnover or company directors' bonuses.

The legislation, which will not be introduced before next spring, was heralded by Mr Prescott as he said lives were being lost in industries such as construction through sheer bad working practice.

"Company directors whose negligence costs lives must not be allowed to hide behind workers and get away with it scot-free," he told delegates.

Each year, 400 people die in the workplace, with 1m injured, 29,000 seriously, at a cost to the taxpayer of £18bn.

In addition, some 350 die each year in transport accidents - with 31 killed last year in the Paddington rail crash. The new legislation will also cover transport safety, and is expected to incorporate the recommendations of Lord Cullen whose inquiry into the Paddington disaster, and the wider issue of rail regulation and safety, will report back next spring.

Mr Prescott also announced a goal to wipe out fuel poverty by 2010, and stressed that the government aimed to help the elderly and disabled by introducing half price bus fares for them all.

He attacked The Countryside Alliance, many of whom were demonstrating outside the conference centre, and drew cheers as he insisted the government had to stand firm on the fuel crisis.

Ken Livingstone yesterday threatened legal action if John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, pressed ahead with his plans to part-privatise the London Underground, after an independent report damned them as offering poor value for money and potentially risking the safety of passengers.

London's mayor, who is due to take over the tube only after the private contracts are locked in place, said it would now be unreasonable in law for the government to carry on with its public-private partnership unless there were radical changes to the scheme.

His remarks were made as government sources said that conflict between the Treasury and Mr Prescott's Transport and Environment Department over how to finance tube modernisation were hampering attempts to achieve a workable political compromise over the issue.

Tony Blair conceded during the London mayoral election that it would be difficult to go ahead with part-privatisation of the tube if Mr Livingstone were elected, but the government now appears determined to force through the scheme.

Yesterday's report by Will Hutton, chief executive of the Industrial Society think tank, commissioned at Labour's insistence, argued that the PPP should be abandoned in favour of a bond-financed public sector option, unless tougher safeguards on safety, contract compliance and value for money are introduced.

"I would have thought to proceed now in the light of Will Hutton's complaints, unless they adapt and take on board his points, there is an opening for a judicial review of the decision," said Mr Livingstone.

"I am not opposed to partnership with the private sector on principle, but this is a rotten deal which binds London for 30 years to overgenerous contracts giving private sector monopolies intolerable powers over London's democratically-elected authorities".

The Rail Maritime and Transport union's senior tube official, Bob Crow, yesterday raised the prospect of a strike over safety on the London Underground, while Mick Rix, general secretary of the train drivers' union Aslef, said the Hutton report had blown a hole through the government's case for PPP.

"The government must now think again and start listening to the trade unions, the elected London mayor and Londoners who voted for him on a platform of a properly funded, publicly owned future for the tube."

The ale is looking increasingly flat at Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, the maker of traditional tipples such as Banks's, Marston's and Pedigree bitter.

Wolves brushed aside a takeover proposal from the private equity firm Botts & Co with surprising arrogance last month, to the irritation of many of its shareholders. At the time, the management dropped non-too-subtle hints that there would be pleasing surprises in this month's trading statement.

That statement flopped on to investors' doormats yesterday offering little comfort - the fullest flavour on offer was a less than booming 1.2% increase in like-for-like sales during August. The brewer is, at best, back on schedule with the integration of recently acquired Marston's and Mansfield, after suffering a severe bout of hiccups in the spring.

Wolves' long-term problem is that it makes ale which, while enjoyed by purists, hardly attracts the cachet of a vodka and Red Bull. The management's response has been to get bigger, in the hope that economies of scale will drive profits forward. So, through a series of takeovers, Wolves has cornered the market in running street-corner boozers in towns in the midlands and north.

Cost cutting is continuing - Wolves is likely to announce imminently that at least one, possibly two, of its four breweries is to go. It has done little with one of its few promising businesses: Pitcher & Piano, a bar chain inherited from Marston's. It is a sad fact of life that the traditional brewing industry is in a slow, long-term decline. Wolves' management has aggravated the situation by trying to do too much, too fast. Botts & Co is hardly the most credible bidder for a £470m business - it is struggling to decide whether to pay £12m for the even less glamorous Oriental Restaurants Group.

But for Wolves, a tight control on costs will be insufficient to satisfy the market's insatiable desire for growth. The best place for the company is in private hands - the question is, whether it will fall to a careful owner.

Exchange stakes

Here is an obscure fact concerning the fight for control of the London Stock Exchange: a portion of the declared 3.6% stake in the exchange held by the investment bank UBS Warburg is in fact beneficially owned by its hedge fund, UBS O'Connor.

The fund was set up in June, drawing together a sizeable group of UBS Warburg's top risk-taking traders in Chicago and London to manage money provided by the parent bank and any of the investment bank's clients who fancied a seriously professional flutter in a high-risk, high-reward world.

How or why UBS O'Connor ended up with a stake in the LSE remains a mystery, although it is assumed the hedge fund thought this particular corporate play to be a good punt. Indeed, since the LSE's demutualisation in mid-summer, the shares have moved from a low of £19 to a recent high of close to £31 - a capital gain of 63% for a well timed speculation in less than two months.

Understandably, the bank does not discuss individual trading positions. The size of its holding is unknown, but is thought to be relatively small. What is clear cut is that the hedge fund manager is holding the stake for one reason: to make money.

Sentimentality over a 200-year-old British institution will not get in the way; neither will the broader implications for UBS, one of the City's premier banks, stemming from a change of ownership of the exchange. Hedge funds only exist to provide their investors with exceptional returns on their money. Should this bother us? For all the debate over institutions becoming more socially aware in their investment choices, financial markets are overwhelmingly driven by the short-term profit motive. Making a speculative gain on the future of the exchange is perhaps just an especially cute bet. (It is also worth noting here that numerous senior staff at the exchange have taken personal punts on the future of the business by buying shares in the London Stock Exchange for themselves.)

Yet somehow the brazen nature of UBS's action feels uncomfortable. In the main, the holding in the LSE is a legacy of its past takeover of two building blocks of London's modern financial community, SG Warburg and Phillips & Drew. The bank may argue now that it is impossible to act simultaneously as a shareholder in the exchange while being one of its prime customers - and it is evident that this peculiarity has muddled quite a few stockbroking brains over recent months. It may also argue that, as a separate hedge fund operation, UBS O'Connor is given its own head, being left to pursue value wherever its dealers manage to spot it.

But whatever the chinese walls and other internal procedures at UBS, the parent bank risks being badly misunderstood when it comes to debating and eventually deciding the LSE's future.

Labour's pensions minister was booed and heckled yesterday by angry OAPs as he attempted to defend the government's refusal to restore the link between earnings and benefits.

At the most inflammatory fringe meeting of the Labour conference, Jeff Rooker struggled to make himself heard as pensioners drowned out his speech with cries of: "Restore the link."

Mr Rooker misjudged the mood of the 500 pensioners when he told the meeting, after a powerful speech by the veteran campaigner Barbara Castle, that he wanted to "dispel a few myths". As he reeled off statistics about pensions, saying that less people were now subjected to means tests, members of the audience shouted "give us our pensions back" and "you don't listen to us". Sweating and looking unsettled, Mr Rooker provoked the audience when he leant over to one noisy pensioner and said: "I'm worried about your health, don't have a heart attack." The pensioner replied that he had already suffered a heart attack.

Jack Jones, the veteran former transport union leader, attempted to calm the atmosphere with an appeal for quiet. But this failed to silence the protestors who continued to barrack Mr Rooker. "Will you shut up while I'm speaking please," he said.

Mr Rooker brought his speech to an abrupt end and hurried back to the safety of the main conference hall to listen to Gordon Brown's speech.

Lady Castle, who introduced the link between pensions and earnings in the 1970s, was given a rapturous reception as she entered the meeting, which was also attended by veteran Labour MP Tony Benn and the agony aunt Clare Rayner. Supported by an aide, the frail 89-year-old former cabinet minister demanded a restoration of the link to ensure that future pensioners are protected. "We are fighting for the restoration of the welfare state and the abolition of the mentality of the poor law - don't let it come back," she said.

Jack Jones was applauded as he told the meeting that this year's increase in the basic state pension of 75p had been "derisory". He said that there were billions of pounds in the National Insurance fund which could be spent on boosting pensions. "It's our money and that money should be released by way of substantial increases to the pensioners this year," he said. "We are not asking for the moon."

Mr Benn joked that he was an "apprentice pensioner" at the age of 76. Saying that pensioners' concerns have been "brushed aside" for too long, he used Gerald Kaufman's famous description of Labour's 1983 election manifesto to underline the importance of restoring the earnings link.

"The decision not to link pensions and earnings is the shortest suicide note in history," he said. "The people in this room are the people who served in the war, voted Labour and gave us all the achievements we have had."

Sotheby's former chairman, Alfred Taubman, has agreed to pay $186m (£130m) out of his own pocket to help the auction house settle US lawsuits with shareholders and customers over a continuing price-fixing scandal.

Mr Taubman, the controlling shareholder, quit as chairman in February when the allegations surfaced. Sotheby's is accused of colluding with rival auctioneer Christie's to keep commission rates high.

In a settlement with former customers, Sotheby's has agreed to stump up $256m, of which it will pay $50m cash and $50m in discount vouchers. Mr Taubman will provide the rest. Sotheby's has also agreed to distribute $40m of stock to angry shareholders, with another $30m of cash from Mr Taubman.

Mr Taubman is one of America's richest businessmen. He made millions from shopping malls before becoming chairman of Sotheby's, which he has controlled since 1983.

"I endorse and am contributing to these settlements to facilitate the resolution of all matters and to minimise the impact on Sotheby's, a company I care about deeply," he said.

Mr Taubman has control of the auctioneer through a large holding of B shares - which carry 10 times the votes of ordinary A shares. It is unclear whether he will sell to finance the settlements.

Christie's, which is co-defendant in the US lawsuits, has agreed to pay similar sums to shareholders and former customers. Some lawsuits, which refer to transactions outside the US, remain outstanding.

After a period of intense competition in the 1980s, Sotheby's and Christie's both raised their commission levels on sales in the early 1990s.

They then both introduced similar sliding scales, charging commissions of between 2% and 10%. The US department of justice is investigating whether collusion took place. Sotheby's said it was in "serious negotiations" with the department and believed a mutually acceptable resolution would soon be reached.

An investigation by Britain's office of fair trading was passed on to the European commission, which is still looking into the matter.

 Jeremy Hardy (Pass at red, September 25) is wrong to say that some rail companies don't want to install automatic train protection because of the cost. The train protection and warning system (TPWS), which is currently being fitted to track and trains, will mitigate the effects of 70% of signals passed at danger by the time it is fully installed by the scheduled date of end-2003. And if current trends continue, it will be a large proportion of a small number (the number of incidents in July 2000 - latest figures - was half that of July 1999).

We cannot fit additional further automatic train protection (ATP) yet, for these reasons: European law requires that any new system should be "interoperable" (capable of being used on any EU railway without modification). Neither of the systems currently installed in Britain is likely to comply. The European Train Control System has been developed to meet that requirement and is currently being tested at various levels of sophistication. When it is ready, we shall install it in Britain. It will prevent trains passing red signals. Until then, the best option is to use our existing systems of ATP and install TPWS, as Sir David Davies recommended in his report in February.

Ian MacKellar
Association of Train Operating Companies
Ian.MacKellar.atoc@ems.rail.co.uk

An obscure recommendation in a government report could pave the way for gay and lesbian couples legally to conceive children together, it has been claimed.

Calum MacKellar, an Edinburgh-based biochemist and ethicist, argues that the recent Donaldson report on human cloning and embryonic cell research opened up a legal loophole allowing same-sex conception, and that science could soon catch up with it.

But an authority in the field said yesterday that the research breakthroughs needed to allow gay or lesbian couples to become biological parents of children were too far away for the government to think about changing the law.

The Donaldson report will form the basis for any changes to the law. One of its little noticed recommendations is that the technology involved in Dolly the sheep style animal cloning should be used to help women with defective eggs to become pregnant.

Under this system, gene-carrying chromosomes would be removed from the nucleus of a woman's defective egg and placed inside a donor egg which had had its genetic material removed. Sperm from the woman's partner would be used to fertilise the egg.

Since this is not cloning, it has attracted little controversy. But Dr MacKellar claims it could be interpreted as allowing the creation of "male eggs", where the chromosomes from sperm are used instead of genetic material from a woman's egg. A second man's sperm would then fertilise the egg.

But Azim Surani, of the Institute of Cancer and Developmental Biology in Cambridge, said nature had placed a barrier in the way of two fathers or two mothers conceiving children together which for the foreseeable future looked insurmountable.

"If you try to make an embryo with two paternal sets of genes, these embryos will die very shortly after birth," said Professor Surani. "You cannot get a viable offspring under any circumstances if you only have a paternal contribution. You really do require a contribution from the mother."

A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "If at some point in the future this becomes a practical possibility, the expert group may want to further consider the issues which may be raised."

Before my husband was imprisoned in Liberia prison for espionage last month, my knowledge of West Africa was limited to a Blue Peter summer special (circa 1974) when the team went off to the Ivory Coast. I remember it looked beautiful and the team kept saying they were exhilarated. I am now more familiar with African politics and know the names (and some of the telephone numbers) of the area's leaders.

David is a television producer- director. He spent most of last year making a series for Channel 4 about the hairdressing chain, Vidal Sassoon. Early this summer, tired of bobs and shampoo, he accepted a job to make a film about Liberia and its government. He was thrilled to have the chance to go to Africa and tell a big international story.

We spoke several times after he arrived. He told me that filming was difficult and access to President Charles Taylor was being denied, although he had agreed to be interviewed. I began to feel really uncomfortable and my two small boys and I started to count the "sleeps" left before David would be home.

Then I got the call. It was about 9.30pm on Friday August 18. On television, Friends had just finished. I never got to see Frasier. David said his room had been searched and his tapes had been seized but he was OK. There was nothing to worry about. He was on schedule to leave on Sunday and would be home by Monday. But there was something in his voice that I didn't recognise at first. Fear.

Next day, at lunchtime, David's executive producer called to tell me that my husband had been arrested and had spent the night in a police cell. This couldn't be happening. The idea that the sweetest, most innocent man in the world, whose only brush with the law was being drunk in charge of a moped as a student, could be banged up in a Liberian cell was beyond belief.

I rang round friends and family. My father-in-law came round and occupied the boys while I tried to get more information. I called a friend of ours, Roy Ackerman, a South African-born television executive who said he would call his uncle, who knew Nelson Mandela. It sounded like a long shot. Friends started to turn up at the house and a campaign committee formed in my kitchen. We started to lobby the Foreign Office, the United Nations and the World Bank. But by the end of the first day, I knew little other than David was still being detained. I felt utterly powerless.

Somehow, I slept for about five hours. At 6am, I called the production company that had hired David and screamed at the executive producer, whom I had woken. We had a very animated conversation. He was tense and tired and told me to stop "crapping on his head"; he didn't have any more news. At 7am, the Liberian story was the third item on the Radio 4 news. My husband was named. I unplugged the radio and television, preferring news from the ground. At 9am, my sister took my boys to Legoland. I hadn't told them anything. I wanted to keep them in their happy summer-of-fun bubble.

Then my world went mad. I received a call from the Foreign Office telling me that next day David would be charged with espionage and sent to prison.

By lunchtime on Sunday, reality had taken on a whole new look. Nelson Mandela had telephoned President Taylor and asked for the four to be released. This was unbelievable - but there was more to come. Jesse Jackson, the US special African envoy, went live on CNN to plead for David's release. There I was, chain-smoking in the garden of my north London house, and there was Jackson, one of the most influential politicians on the planet, talking on what is arguably the most politically influential television channel on the planet, about my husband and the wellbeing of his family.

Shortly after his appearance on CNN, I was asked by Jackson's office if I would like to give the special envoy a statement or ask any questions. I had five minutes to think about it. We scratched our heads. "What about getting him to sort out your resident's parking?" my father-in-law suggested. Once the nervous laughter died, we dictated a few lines about David, his innocence and his credibility as a film-maker.

I received another call from the Foreign Office, this time asking me to dictate a message that the European consul in Liberia would be able to pass to David. I told him I was strong and fighting, I told him the boys were fine and in Legoland.

The next day, things deteriorated. "The Liberian Four", as the media had named them, were charged and sent to prison. There was talk of a trial in November. I was reassured that the four men were together, separated from other prisoners and in good spirits. The prison was "really clean, for Africa".

Tim Gardam, the director of programmes at Channel 4, called me. In television mythology, this man is a god and people like me don't get to talk to him, let alone shout expletives at him. He was sympathetic and deeply upset. But I still shouted at him: "He's my love, he's my life, you've got to get him home."

My house had turned into a 24- hour drop-in centre for concerned friends and family who comforted, humoured and organised a running buffet of mixed delicacies - pork pies, doughnuts and caviar, all the things people know I love. I couldn't swallow any of it. But boy, could I smoke.

During a late night think-in, our friend Roy came up with the name George Weah - a Manchester City footballer and, apparently, the most famous Liberian in the world. It took me a while to get the power of the footie thing. The influence Beckham would have on Tony Blair, Roy assured me, was not a good comparison.

Then came the Colonel Gadafy connection. A friend in the US had spoken to former president Jimmy Carter who suggested, bizarrely, that I fly to Libya and meet the colonel. Gadafy is apparently close to Taylor and happy to help out in difficult international situations. He would appreciate a personal visit from a wife, I was told. But how could I leave my children?

Wednesday was grim. I got a call saying David had been beaten up. I cracked. I was sick. More calls were made to Mandela and Jackson. A few hours later, Gardam called to say that David hadn't been beaten up. He had been psychologically abused. We agreed to meet the following day.

I took Roy, my sister and my father-in-law with me. We had a brief, but vivid, meeting at Channel 4 and then went to the Foreign Office where our moods were soon lifted. We met James Watt, the head of the consular division. Things, he assured us, were happening. The chairman of Channel 4 had written to Taylor apologising for any action the crew might have taken to cause offence, and undertook not to continue with the film. The four men had also apologised to the Liberian government. The British ambassador to the Ivory Coast was in Monrovia, holding meetings with the Liberian justice minister.

Jim Gavin, who has died aged 89, was one of the last surviving climbers to attempt Mount Everest before the second world war. A capable skier and sailor, he was also a distinguished soldier, who made a dramatic wartime escape from the Japanese, and later worked for the Special Operations Executive.

Gavin was born in Chile, and educated at St Peter's school, in Santiago, and Uppingham school, Rutland. After the Royal Military Academy and a commission in the Royal Engineers, he read mechanical engineering at Trinity College, Cambridge, from 1931, and took up climbing with the university mountaineering club in the Bernese Oberland.

He climbed with some of the best of his day - including Colin Kirkus and Frank Smythe - and his physical toughness so impressed Smythe that he suggested to Hugh Ruttledge, leader of the 1936 Everest expedition, that the relatively young lieutenant would be an asset on the mountain.

Two reconnaissance expeditions had earlier looked at Everest, and three fullscale attempts had failed to reach the summit, but the 1936 team looked strong on paper, with Gavin one of only two newcomers to a group that included Smythe, Eric Shipton, Charles Warren and Percy Wyn Harris. Although Gavin had no Himalayan experience, he nevertheless helped Smythe open the route to the north col that season, raising hopes of an early summit attempt. Sadly, these were thwarted by the arrival of the monsoon.

The following year, Gavin and his Cambridge contemporary, Ashley Greenwood, climbed together in Chamonix, attempting a traverse of the Aiguilles des Drus, during which a fellow officer had his dislocated shoulder reset in the middle of a steep mountain. Gavin returned to Chamonix in 1940, having temporarily given up his commission in the Royal Engineers to join a Scots Guards skiing battalion. The plan was to enter and support Finland - then at war with the Soviet Union - via neutral Sweden; in the event, it came to nothing, and the skiers left in a hurry as the Germans took control of France.

Gavin then embarked on a sabotage mission to Norway, but after his submarine was badly damaged by depth charges, the expedition was abandoned and Gavin moved to the mountain warfare school at Loch Ailort. In 1941, he was sent to Singapore to open a commando training centre and launch a sabotage campaign in Malaya against the advancing Japanese. But little was accomplished, and he found himself, as a valued officer, with the chance to get out as Singapore fell in early 1942.

He had, however, fallen in love with Barbara Murray and, with only wives allowed to accompany departing officers, they quickly married and flew to Sumatra. They would have 53 years together, and two daughters and a son.

T he Japanese had destroyed much of the local Sumatra shipping, and Gavin and Barbara at first found themselves marooned. But as an engineer and a keen sailor, who had participated in the Fastnet race, he was able to rig up a tug, and together they sailed to Ceylon before embarking by train for northern India.

It was during a riot on the train that Gavin suffered the heart attack that was to break his health, and leave him considerably weaker for the rest of his life. After recuperating in Kashmir, he re turned to Europe to work on sabotage equipment for SOE. In 1944, on the verge of being parachuted into northern Italy from his post in Cairo, he was transferred to General Eisenhower's allied headquarters at Versailles.

Gavin went on to hold senior posts with the Royal Engineers, and became a general staff officer at the British joint services mission in Washington, between 1948 and 1951. He then commanded 36 Engineer Regiment at Ripon, was a general staff officer at Camberley, and commanded 11 Engineer Group at Osnabruck. He ended his military career in 1967 as assistant chief of staff (intelligence) at SHAPE, the Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers, Europe.

He then spent 10 years as technical director of the British Standards Institution, working on the introduction of metrication, before retiring to Milland, near Liphook, Hampshire. After his wife died in 1994, he spent the remaining years with his daughter in Dorset.

Markus Lupfer presented his fourth catwalk show yesterday, with a collection for spring and summer that has secured the approbation of buyers and press alike.

The London fashion week venue was unusual, a former church turned sports hall on a trading estate in west London, but it was packed to the rafters with the cream of the fashion crowd, and they did not leave disappointed.

Building on the success of last season, his collection had the usual Lupfer trademarks, supple leathers and bold graphics, but the overriding difference was a giant leap in confidence.

With a tight colour palette of black, cream, green, lilac and blue, he tipped his shallow brimmed trilby in a Mod direction once again.

Masculine leather jackets (with all important shoved-up sleeves) were worn with micro minis and mid-calf colourful boots.

The key print was Prince of Wales check on a cream base with red or blue.

The check was blown up for some bias cut silk dresses with draping cowl necks and floaty sleeves, and used in miniature on high button prim shirts matched with A-line skirts.

In true Lupfer style the check was then juxtaposed with differently weighted fabrics. A check blouse was worn with a pastel blue leather skirt that had ribbons of leather hanging from the waistband; and check trousers were worn with a light black lace top swathed in black and white feathers.

There was even a tribute to cowgirl - a check skirt studded with rhinestones.

Lupfer kept the emphasis on the hips, a trend already in evidence on many other catwalks this season. Bands of smocking adorned the backs of jackets and the bottoms of blouses, cinching them at hip level. Chunky leather belts wrapped skirts which themselves often featured a dropped peplum (waistband), again drawing attention to the hips.

Lupfer followed up last season's photo prints with a series of dresses and separates featuring a flock of birds taking off from water - herons or was it ducks? We could not decide, but my guess is that ducks are too downmarket for the fashion crowd. Then again ... maybe we are getting used to slumming it.

France's political elite was reeling yesterday after the highly damaging allegations of kickbacks centred on the president, Jacques Chirac, spread to embroil a former Socialist finance minister and dragged in the name of the celebratedfashion designer, Karl Lagerfeld.

Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a leading ministerial light until forced by graft allegations to resign from Lionel Jospin's cabinet last year, admitted that for nearly two years he had been sitting on potentially devastating corruption evidence against Mr Chirac.

The disgraced former finance minister confirmed he had been given a now-infamous videotape last April in which Jean-Claude Méry, a property developer and senior official in Mr Chirac's RPR party, directly implicated the president in a vast covert fundraising operation.

Méry recorded the tape before dying of cancer last year. His lawyer gave the cassette to Mr Strauss-Kahn - apparently in the hope that as finance minister he would arrange a massive tax break for another of the lawyer's clients, the couturier Karl Lagerfeld.

Amid mounting suspicion in RPR ranks that the Socialist party was responsible for the release of the tape to French media last week, an embattled President Chirac immediately called for an investigation into "the possible involvement of Mr Strauss-Kahn in this very serious matter".

After a morning crisis meeting the prime minister, Mr Jospin, promised to hold a swift inquiry and said the finance ministry would hand over all relevant documents to magistrates later in the day. Mr Jospin is anxious to prevent any further fallout on his ruling coalition.

Mr Strauss-Kahn, a lawyer by training and a close friend of the prime minister, admitted he had received the original of the tape from Méry's counsel, Alain Belot, but denied he had ever watched it and claimed he did not even know where it was.

"I knew Belot as a tax lawyer and because he had worked with the parliament's tax committee," Mr Strauss-Kahn told Le Monde. "He gave me a tape and said: 'Have a look at that, it's interesting.' He said it was about illicit RPR fundraising at Paris town hall, but he never told me the president was implicated."

The former Socialist minister, already under investigation for alleged false accounting at his law firm, could now face charges of obstructing justice for having withheld the tape - especially as Mr Belot is reported to have told police that Mr Strauss-Kahn asked him last week not to reveal the fact that he had the tape.

Before his fall from grace, Mr Strauss-Kahn had been hotly tipped as the Socialist party's candidate for Paris mayor in next year's municipal election. The tape, detailing allegations of institutionalised RPR corruption at Paris town hall, would have been a powerful electoral asset.

Mr Lagerfeld's fashion house declined all comment on the story, but according to French media the couturier was indeed the subject of a big tax investigation and faced a £30m demand last year after it emerged he had not paid any tax in France for six years.

One paper said that he eventually paid just £5m, though there is no evidence that any special favour was granted by the authorities.

Mr Strauss-Kahn rejected all allegations of wrongdoing. He told French radio that he denied "all political connections that people are trying to make, as well as any connections with any tax dossier" involving Mr Lagerfeld.

The extraordinary tale of widespread corruption in high places began to emerge last week when Le Monde printed, in two consecutive issues over some six pages, the transcript of Méry's tape, which the businessman recorded in 1996 "in case anything happens to me".

He claimed that he was in charge of a many-tentacled system whereby construction companies paid big bribes to win maintenance, heating and other contracts for city-owned housing blocks while Mr Chirac was mayor of Paris.

The vast majority of the money, he said, went to Mr Chirac's RPR.

The allegations from beyond the grave, which dropped like a bombshell in Paris and were furiously denied by Mr Chirac, were the latest in a string of corruption accusations levelled against the president pertaining to the period from 1977 to 1995 when he was mayor.

A record abstention rate in a referendum on shortening the presidential term has sent a strong signal to the political establishment that it is out of touch with people's concerns, analysts said yesterday.

Almost 70% of the French electorate failed to vote in Sunday's referendum on whether to cut the head of state's time in office from seven to five years, aligning it with the parliamentary term and with most of Europe.

The change was approved by 73% of those who bothered to vote, but it was the abstention rate - the highest in the nine referendums held during the fifth republic - that grabbed the headlines.

"A little Yes, but a big slapdown," was the verdict of Le Parisien, while Libération and France Soir referred to "the vote strike" and the conservative Le Figaro called the poll "a huge political and symbolic failure".

Most commentators agreed on the value of the reform. The presidential mandate was out of synch with parliament's five-year term, leading to paralysing "cohabitations" between presidents and prime ministers of different political persuasions that block real institutional change.

"Today, it's clear that the path towards reform of our institutions is open," said Dominique Chagnollaud, a constitutional law professor. "No matter who is elected president in 2002, he will not be able to avoid far-reaching institutional reform."

But many criticised the method President Jacques Chirac chose to ratify the reform. France's constitution can be changed by a special joint congress of the upper and lower houses of parliament, and putting such an arcane issue to the people was, analysts said, inappropriate.

But the main reason for the indifference was that most French people are more concerned by practical issues such as soaring petrol prices, their heavy tax burden, and the current corruption saga tainting many in the political class.

Cable operators in India last night blacked out TV screens in almost 1m homes in protest at a new broadcasting law which holds them directly responsible for showing adult programmes, and for screening advertisements for beer and cigarettes.

The operators say it is "ridiculous" to blame them for the contents of India's mostly mediocre 70 TV channels and claim it is the broadcasters who should be the target of government legislation.

The strike, which is set to go on for three days, has so far only affected Delhi, completely wiping out coverage of the Olympics and all state-run channels.

"So far we have only hit Delhi. But unless the government wakes up soon and does something about the law the strike will spread to Bombay and across the country," Vikki Chowdhry, of the Cable TV Operators United Front said last night. "We are not responsible for what is on TV. The government must scrap this lopsided legislation."

There was confusion in gov ernment circles as to what, exactly, would fall foul of the new cable network act. By western standards, Indian TV is remarkably chaste with no full frontal nudity and not much kissing. The country's most risque channel is Fashion TV, which shows models gliding down the catwalk, while Indian actresses are required to do nothing more suggestive in Hindi movies than to gyrate in the obligatory wet sari scene.

Under the new legislation cable operators will receive a warning if they are deemed to be transmitting obscene material. They then face arrest if they repeat the offence. Delhi's police chief Dr K K Paul, yesterday claimed that certain operators were flouting the rules by transmitting pornography in the early hours of the morning. "If they are as clean as they say they are, then why are they going ahead with the strike?" he asked.

The law which came into effect two weeks ago has attracted the wrath of India's tobacco advertisers who say they spend only 1% of funds on TV ads. The industry claims that such adverts are shown at times when children are unlikely to be watching. The law's only immediate casualty appears to be adverts for Kingfisher, one of India's most popular beers, which have now been pulled.

India's broadcasting minister, Arun Jaitley, has defended the new act, which comes amid wider moves to liberalise Indian TV, including a decision two months ago allowing foreign companies to broadcast to India via cable for the first time.

"We are a liberal society. We will ban cable operators only in the rarest of rare cases. Power to ban any channel is only with central government," Mr Jaitley insisted.

But under the new, more stringent rules shows deemed to be adult, previously only broadcast between 11pm and6am, have been banned completely. "All programmes will now have to be in conformity with the code prescribing norms of decency, morality and national security," a government spokesman said. An estimated 50m Indians own TV sets, with another 100m believed to have access to television.

HMS Anon, an unnamed 4,000-tonne destroyer, hurtled past Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty at 32 knots and set course to ram-raid the twin towers of the World Trade Center on Manhattan Island.

The fog came down over New York and the captain did a stomach-churning swerve in a rolling 10ft sea to avoid a buoy. Then he slid the vessel, which had by this time metamorphosed into a 30,000-tonne container ship, deftly between a couple of other boats and made full speed backwards.

Earlier, without leaving his berth in a factory unit on a Birkenhead industrial estate, the skipper had taken the same container ship on a run down the misty Mersey (Eastham docks to port, Liverpool's twin cathedrals to starboard) and past the Pier Head. Night fell, lights twinkled and the vessel snuggled through Gladstone Lock and into Seaforth docks.

So ended the sea trials of a £1.6m maritime equivalent of a flight simulator installed by Liverpool's John Moores University next to the Cammell Laird shipyard.

It is Britain's first ship simulator with a full 360 degree field of vision, which enables learner drivers to check whether the back end of the boat is smacking into the dock when they make a tight turn.

Chief mates, master and marine pilots keen to improve their skills stand in a five-tonne replica of ship's bridge, complete with charts and radar screens, and are required to cope with all the perils of the sea: 100 knot gales, tide changes, engine failure, instrument breakdown.

"If you had wanted to, could you have rammed that other ship?" someone asked Bert Kunze, director of the Lairdside Maritime Centre where the simulator is housed. "Yes, but that's not the object of the exercise," he replied. "If I had, the image would have shaken a bit. But no bits of metal would have fallen off and we have no collision sound effects.

"The object is to allow mariners to practise their skills in a safe environment. If they run aground here, there is no harm done to the ship - and no pollution."

Twelve video projectors and computer graphics can create a variety of port land and seascapes, including Felixstowe and the ship-packed English Channel, and changing conditions are used to test the team work of crews.

"In any group, one or two people will treat it as a joke," added Mr Kunze. "But after a couple of minutes, they forget the jokes and really get into it because it feels so much like the real thing.

"Ships loom suddenly out of the fog as in real life and it's interesting to hear the comments of the students. Usually it's an expletive followed by a large helm order."

The last time UK cinemagoers saw Christopher Walken, he was rampaging round a late 19th-century American town, wielding a sword and butchering the locals. His dialogue was minimal but effective - "GnnnnrraaaaaGGGhhh! NnnnraaAAAAaaggghhh!!!" - as he hacked his way through Tim Burton's Hammer tribute Sleepy Hollow.

Which is no surprise. Measured by his screen persona, the 57-year-old actor is anything but normal. Take the wheelchair-ridden Man With The Plan in Things To Do In Denver When You're Dead, or the psychotic mob boss Vincenzo Coccotti in True Romance. Indeed, many thought his performance as the demented Frank White in the super-violent gangster flick King Of New York was his most extreme - until last year's Wildside showed him whipping his chauffeur with his underpants while attempting to sodomise him at gunpoint.

Recently, however, Walken went even further when he came up with an idea for a TV show that was so far out, nobody would touch it. MTV said no, Bravo said no. The Comedy Channel said no. So what was so dangerous about this show? Was it America's Best-Loved Serial Killers? How To Raise The Dead? The Murder Roadshow? No, Walken simply wanted his own cookery programme.

"It was either 10 or 12 segments," he recently told the New York Observer. "I can't remember. I was going to have some sort of kitchen set-up. I wanted it to be a little like Pee-Wee's Playhouse. I love that show. And I would have maybe a showgirl, you know, with a little thing on, chopping my vegetables. Maybe some musicians. And an audience. Some people to talk to."

If this seems a little unusual, perhaps some perspective is required here. Walken's father, 97, is a German immigrant who ran a bakery in the New York suburb of Queens. Walken was considering joining the family business and often worked for his father, putting the jam in doughnuts, but a shambolic stint as a delivery boy convinced him otherwise.

Today, cooking remains one of Walken's private hobbies, and he rarely eats out. "I'm amazed people let total strangers mess around with their food," he once said. "When I cook for myself, I know what I'm getting. I use good stuff. I'm not a great chef, I don't have a repertoire, but if you buy the right things and cook them very simply it has to be good."

Since his breakthrough performance in the harrowing 1978 Vietnam drama The Deer Hunter, Walken has led something of a double life. While his screen roles become all the more bizarre, his home life seems all the more normal. Not many people know, for example, that his real name is Ronnie, and that he trained as a dancer in stage school. The name change was suggested by a Belgian songstress, who hired Walken as part of a trio of backing singers/hoofers in her nightclub act. "You know," she told him, "I don't really like 'Ronnie'. I think you're more 'Christopher'. Do you mind if I call you Christopher?" Walken said, "Call me anything you like, just don't call me late for lunch."

As a child, Walken and his brother did modelling and advertising work, and at the age of 10 he would get the subway to Manhattan with his brother and hang around the TV studios. He appeared in the background of many family TV shows, such as The Colgate Comedy Hour, and one of his fondest memories is taking part in a sketch with Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis. As a teenager, he pursued a song and dance career, and it was during a 60s production of West Side Story that he met his future wife, Georgianne. They married in 1969, and the pair have been together ever since, sharing their small farmstead a few hours outside New York City with their cats.

Indeed, it wasn't until 1977, some 30 years into his career, that Walken began to be considered a menacing movie presence, when he landed a small but memorable part as Annie Hall's death-obsessed brother Duane in Woody Allen's hit movie. Duane opened the floodgates, and nowadays, anything goes. In the last 20 years, Walken's fans have seen him causing metaphysical carnage as the angel Gabriel (Prophecy parts l and II) and disco-dancing with aliens after receiving an anal probe (Communion). Strangely, however, these people can't imagine Christopher Walken sitting at home, stroking the cats, dancing with his wife or whipping up a tasty pasta sauce.

"If I wasn't so lazy, I'll tell you what I would do," he told the NY Observer. "I saw this thing on television. This whole thing with people putting cameras in their house, for the net. I thought I'd get a couple of those cameras and put them in my kitchen and just, you know, turn it on whenever I felt like it. Maybe I would have a particular time of day I would do it, or something like that. And to make it amusing, I thought I would have a hotline - you know, a red telephone. And they could call and I could give them advice about their love life...

"You remember a programme called This Is Your Life? I thought I'd have a curtain over to one side and once in a while I'd have a mystery guest. You know, actors are always coming over to my house. Maybe Joe Pesci comes over and makes his tomato sauce. Everybody makes something, you know what I mean? Don't you think that might be amusing?"

Whatever you say, Mr Walken.
